author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
__**TLDR 2 - the return**__ - The final word. If I was asked “What sample rate should people make records at in 2022?” And was forced to choose then the answer would be 48k. Why?

- Film and TV prefer it
- Labels prefer it
- *(I hate Atmos)* Atmos is at 48k *(I hate Atmos)*
- There are small but meaningful technical and sonic advantages
- It doesn’t place demands on CPU or drive space

author: cian riordan
content:
1) a strong work ethic: You have to be willing to put in the time and energy into the project. You will always be the first person there and the last to leave. Once you accept this and work it into your life, it just becomes the way it is!

2) a good personality: You need to be good around people. Half of this job is psychological. You have to know when to speak up as well as when to not say anything. Talkback etiquette is crucial. Learn to read people. Never get angry or passive aggressive. You always need to be voice of reason. People have to trust you.

3) a solid skill-set: You have to always know what your doing and be confident in your abilities. Know the technical side of things. You should also be musically inclined. Be curious! Why does a song sound a certain way? How did they do it? If you don't care and don't want to know – you should do something else.

4) actual follow through: You'd be surprised how many flaky people work in this business. If you're a guy that does things when you say you'll do them and answers phonecalls/emails in a timely manner, then you're already leagues above most other people.

5) the ability to network with people and capitalize on your relationships is the only way to move forward in this business. Going to shows, parties, events, etc. You never know where work is going to come from.

Your work gets you work. Make sure everything you do is the best representation of your abilities. Don't choose which projects to care more about. Give it your all on everything... even if its a shitty gig. That word will spread and you'll start getting more work through that.

Hope this helpful. Good luck!

author: cian riordan
content: Agreed -- be critical of everything. Be critical of things that are expensive for the sake of being expensive. Things that are just  instagram ads shilling to newbies. Critical of  Greg Wells pandering to whatever his base is. But recommending a 4k converter based on 'audible conversion quality' isn't helpful if the consumer doesn't have a million other ducks in a row first -- room treatment, adequate monitoring, proper gainstaging, etc. Jon has that figured out, so it makes sense for him. But when people come into a forum with questionable knowledge and background in music production asking what's the best converter, I think it's fair to ask some prying questions before just making blanket recommendations on what one person heard or not. I have plenty of semi-OK stuff that still gets used on the regular, and plenty of expensive gear that I would happily toss out of my workflow. They're all just tools. And whether its bougie DW Fearn or a black-friday Acustica plugin, , if it works for your workflow and gets you results you're happy with, then its worth whatever money you're willing to pay for it.

author: BatMeckley
content: So much good advice here, but I’ll just add: no one gives you a plaque that says “you’re a producer” or “you’re an artist”. You are because you do. Just keep doing, keep trying to find any avenue to push you’re knowledge/experience/discography forward. Every record you make you’ll learn something new AND you’re already getting paid for your work (win). Spoiler alert: You’ll NEVER feel like you REALLY know what you’re doing. If you do, you’ve lost (I know this must sound odd coming from someone who @cian riordan  thinks is so knowledgeable and brilliant) Satisfaction breeds mediocrity. Music is far too vast for anyone to fully understand    everything in their lifetime. Bake that into the equation as you try to figure out how you feel about where you’re at.

Finding this place feels like part of a bigger second chance I’ve been given, I try every day to treat it as such, and great things have happened because of it

author: BatMeckley
content:
You keep getting the right answer. And you keep swearing it’s the wrong one. 

Release some songs. 

The quote above about hindsight is so spot on. If you have 16 full lengths RELEASE A SONG. You can always redo it with the wisdom you’ve gained in hindsight. But you keep asking for help, because you don’t know the answer, you keep getting the answer, and then you go “no that’s not the answer”. It IS the answer. This is how to get where you want to go. 

I totally get that living in the potential is cozy and safe. But it’s not how you actually progress. You have to face the actual. And if you don’t, you won’t. No amount of discord or Reddit is going to actually get you there. It’s like a guy going on a body building forum for two years asking about weights and reps and form and saying how he’s not gaining any muscle, and then it comes out that you actually haven’t lifted a weight yet. 

It’s always “I JUST need this, and THEN I can…” but, again, (again again) it’s not. You need to actually listen to the advice or what are we doing here?

author: cian riordan
content:
A tangent…

I’m lucky to have spent many years in a great studio with lots of great drums & gear… not to mention being mentored by one of the great engineers of our time. Having this perspective is massively useful in mixing other peoples tracks, because I feel I have a north star of what good drums can sound like if they’re recorded and performed properly. It used to be that my starting point for mixing drums were working with tracks that I had recorded myself… and most of the above problems were solved before the mix stage. These days, with smaller budgets and time constraints, its very rare that this is a possibility.

I’m including this drum tracking session from a few years ago that I recorded at Barefoot. It was for a project that Matt was producing that never saw the light of day. But we went all out with the drum setup in the big room, through the console, and had a great drummer. This might be useful for some people who have never gotten properly recorded drum tracks… to get a sense of how good thigns can sound before the ‘mix’ stage. These are the tracks that were printed into Pro Tools off of the console, and the three busses were prints of the outboard compressor busses we were using while monitoring. It’s unlikely these busses would get used in mixing, but they’re a good reference to what we were listening to in the room while we were tracking. But as you’ll notice, the individual drum blend can stand on it’s own two feet. Hopefully this is useful as well.

Thanks for coming to my Ted talk.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Haha just relaying my experience. If you're sending to a mastering engineer it's a whole different conversation.

Always think about what you're trying to accomplish at any given stage. Then go after that goal. 

I used to spend too much time on sonics in writing sessions. I should have been solely focused on finding emotional magic. Now  I am just trying to inspire the artists and writers around me, I'll deal with the sonics later. Much better results.

I also used to fully mix-as-I-go, which painted me into a corner with gain staging and eq. Now when I get to the end of the process, I often pull things back and rebuild my levels so there's headroom and I can make that exciting production translate.

Different approaches for different parts of the process.

author: LAPhill
content:
If I can offer one bit of perspective from an outsider - As soon as someone pays you more, that is now your rate from that day forward. Everything else is a discount.

In composer land, I had a client come along and effectively pay me more than double what I was making up to that point. After that, all negotiations were done as that new number being my base rate, and anything less was a discount (I love the idea above of marking that discount on the invoice so your full rate is still shown). I sort of felt guilty for awhile charging that much, thinking I wasn't at that level, but then started to notice most clients instantly started to get pretty close to that number, where before they were half of that. Perception is a VERY powerful thing.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The landscape for pitching songs has changed dramatically in the last decade. It still exists, but it has shrunk to the point where even the top level writers can't rely on it as much.

This is simply because many more people can write songs and make demos quickly. This results in two things: the market is flooded with songs, and artists who used to rely on pitch songs are now writing (or co-writing) the majority of their material.

Many songs that used to be sent to an artist are now brought into the room and finished with the artist themselves. Like, you'd pitch a chorus or a 3/4 finished song to an artist and finish with them on the spot.

The genres where pitching songs still predominates are country the (industry is still writer–driven), EDM (many artists are performers who do not write or produce), and pop (but they're mostly just looking for HITS).

Another consequence of this shrinking pitch landscape is that the projects that need "outside" songs are much more gate-kept by people in the industry. In country, there are publishers and labels that generally source the songs. In pop, labels and executive producers (of specific projects) tend to be the gate keepers, and in EDM it is a similar combo.

So, to answer your question directly, the best way to pitch songs is to build direct relationships with artists or go through the various business people who gate-keep the process.

To advise you based on your question: make incredible records with your friends, peers, and the people around you, and get visibility that way. Hustle like crazy and use every moment of new visibility as a stepping stone to get in the mix with the larger music community. Ultimately you probably sign a publishing deal and sing with a manager where you get business representatives to help guide you and connect you further.

As with all things music, if you actually really for real make A+ records, people will find you. It's just that this is a lot harder than people think.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly, that line is a bit over blown. It’s more “oh the chorus is louder, let’s knock it back a click or two on the input so it doesn’t distort”

We were usually recording songs in fairly small sections, making sure to get the details right. There wasn’t a lot of jedi like fader riding. On very rare occasions if I knew there was going to be a huge dynamic shift I’d reach out and grab the output fader, but I can probably count on one hand how many times I’ve had to do that.

We were fairly conservative on the 1176 on the way in, largely cause you can’t un crunch a vocal that’s been over compressed, but once the vocal was in PT it would be hit by just irresponsible levels of compression and limiting. Like goes against how virtually every “expert” online would tell you how to do it. Most people would tell you the solo’d tracks would sound bad, but as part of the song their impact is objectively unarguable

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
.
Assuming we're talking about fairly typical rock, pop and Hip Hop then this 3 part strategy covers a lot of ground

1) Make sure the EQ is as balanced as you can get it - most of your perceived loudness comes from the arrangement and mid range focus (2k to 8k). Too much low end will sound bad when you limit. Make sure the relationship between 80, 160 and 320 makes sense (think of them a little like fundamental, 1st and 2nd harmonic).

2) Consider shaving snare transients (and maybe kick transients) with a clipper. This spreads that peak energy harmonically across the spectrum, keeping energy, hiding in the noisey nature of snares and lets the limiter work less hard (I like SIR Standardclip - $25, great metering and responds intuitively)

3) Pro-L2 on the settings below is a great start point for clean and predictable limiting, raising input gain until you get the desired level

author: Slow Hand
content:
Let me begin by saying that your feelings and experiences are more common than you may realize. It's alright to feel that way. Though I don't believe it's constructive to dwell on them.

It's not unusual to feel inferior when surrounded by people who are more experienced and talented than you. We've all felt this. The thing is this; you are in exactly the right place and will only benefit from engaging with this environment. Being surrounded by so many professionals and people with experience is absolutely a benefit to your development and someday you'll look back at how far you've come and be amazed by how fluent you are.

Let me drive this point home just a little more: When you were young and learning your native language, nobody put you in a room and expected you to learn the language by conversing with a bunch of inexperienced two year-olds who couldn't speak. Instead, you were surrounded by expert speakers and learned through interactions with people who were leagues ahead of you in their ability to speak the language. Learning to speak is not an easy task, but by immersing yourself in a community of experts you are on the path to mastery and in no time you'll reap the benefits of that exposure.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It's a big topic, but gain staging is about finding the optimal amount of gain at every stage of the recording and mixing process.

Good gain staging allows you to get the best fidelity out of a recording by preventing things from creating unwanted distortion or amplifying unwanted noise. **OR** if you are *seeking* some distortion and compression it's about turning up the gain enough to give you the amount that you're seeking from your tools.

Gain staging is something to be considered at all steps of the production process. For example:

*1. How loud is an amplifier turned up in the room? Is the microphone being blow out by it?

2. How high is the gain on a microphone preamp and is it at risk of clipping if the performer plays loudly?

3. Is the gain so low that when I turn a signal up later on the noise floor will rise with it?

4. If I'm recording to tape, am I recording quiet enough that it won't saturate the signal, or do I want for the signal to slam the tape and be saturated?

5. How loud is an individual channel in a DAW? Is it making the channel clip?

6. How loud is a signal that's being sent into a piece of hardware or a plugin? Am I distorting the circuitry at all?

7. Is my signal coming in so hot that it makes a compressor react way too hard?

8. How loud is the entire track I'm mixing? Is the limiter crushing the dynamics in an unwanted way? Or am I hitting it just with just enough level to get a certain flavor of pumping and clipping?

9. Is my final mix going to hit digital zero and create unwanted clipping?*

So gain staging is not a single thing, but a series of choices that are made every step of the way around how you manage the "voltage" of your signals. Together these choices all add up to a mix that "breathes" well and is free of excessive or unwanted distortion.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I would rule out the Izotope production bundle (Ozone is fine). I think Izotope is the least musical and hit-or-miss of the options. It's not bad, but it's not as fun to use as the other options, and I think that has an effect on your results.

Both the FabFilter Mastering bundle and Soundtoys bundle are great and you wouldn't go wrong with either pick. But they occupy different niches: FabFilter is clean and surgical while Soundtoys is all about injecting vibe and coloration and doesn't include anything remotely surgical.

I guess if you can only pick one I'd start with Soundtoys for the vibe and the way it would expand the sonic palette for your production work. Your DAW is going to have some perfectly capable EQ's and compressors to tide you over until you're ready for FabFilter.

Put another way, your production work is upstream of your mixing work and will influence the sound of your records more.

author: cian riordan
content: I would suggest making sure that you like their output. Listen to things they've mixed and make sure they gel with your aesthetic. There's a technical baseline that you want to ensure your mixer can meet -- it's usually pretty obvious when they're hitting below it. Like Noah said, a personal connection is great because it usually makes the communication a little easier. They'll be less precious about reaching out to you for feedback/additional files/etc and you'll be more candid in your feedback. Also, if you haven't worked with that person, very easy to find people who have and shoot them a quick note. "How was your experience? Would you hire them again?" From there you can just go down the list of pricing, availability, etc.

author: Slow Hand
content: Also, consider that raising your prices will eventually *improve* the caliber of client that you are working with. To understand how that could be, this passage on *Price Transition Shock* does a great job at explaining: https://personalmba.com/price-transition-shock/

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
My take, after listening, was that a ME should have no problem working on the non limited mix. I heard the clipping but it wasn’t ugly. There are lots of things that go into making a record, and a little clipping here and there isn’t gonna be the difference in a song hitting or not. 

But also- allowing yourself to be curious without being fearful... Taking someone’s note and asking, without judgment, if there’s something you might’ve missed, is worthwhile.

Deeper still, and I’m still working this out: taking the blame and taking the credit are the same thing, I think. Admitting you were wrong can be a sort of superpower, and all the sting and shame disappear and all you’re left with is the learning and growing and relationship building. Walls go down on all sides and it becomes a team effort again. 

It’s real easy to let ego ruin a good feeling. Being able to say “shit what did I miss?” is wayyyy easier than saying “but I already said it was good so i can’t go back on it…” it takes longer to get there sometimes, but in the end it’s the path of least resistance. 

BBQ Sauce.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I have a couple distinct phases of my workflow. The “technical” phase let’s call it, is all about letting my brain objectively search for the very specific kinds of things that are distracting within the mix at hand. This is much more of a thinking and corrective process than it is a feeling one, even though feeling and taste is 100% involved. This part of the process is to get the mix on a more solid foundation if needed.

The next phase is where I want to actively NOT be thinking at all. This is why I do the first part separately. I want to be FEELING the music in this phase and not be taken out of it by the vocal resonance at 1.8k at 1:35 in the bridge. I want to turn that part of my brain off so I can focus on the music, the feeling, the lyrics, the intent, the song and try to find where (or if) I can elevate or reveal or better frame the heart of what’s there. This is meant to be the flow state, moving intuitively and viscerally based on what’s coming out of the speakers. This is where efficiency in toolset matters -- where an extremely efficient human-computer interaction matters, where knowing your tools cold matters. I want to reduce latency between feeling and move and I don’t want anything to get in my way. 

So to answer your question: I think about ways to continue to be able to access and preserve that crucial flow state during the time where it matters the most. And it can manifest a million ways that aren’t directly related to mastering at all: taking a walk, working out, doing a J, listening to a new record, checking Discord, unplugging, whatever. And yes, sometimes it also means refining my template or my Streamdeck shortcuts or creating a new preset.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Great responses above. One other thing to conceptualize is guitar amps. Many guitar amps have built in spring reverb. If you mic that amp with a single mic, that mono signal has the reverb as a part of it. When you pan that complete signal, it carries a kind of depth and character that is very different from a stereo reverb or even a separate send. 

Mono elements with their own reverb can achieve an interesting spatial clarity that you can't get with eq or compression or whatever else you use to give elements their own place in a mix. I use it on all kinds of things from guitars to vocals to drums to whatever.

author: cian riordan
content:
Mixing Drums:

After now listening to many of Jon & Matt’s podcasts, as well as existing on this discord for a while, I’ve found myself feeling a little perplexed by people’s ability to mix things so fast. It finally clicked that many folks these days (especially in the pop world) are getting stems to mix from — not full multitrack sessions — and often not real drumsets/instruments in real rooms. In my world, for better or worse, I’m almost always getting multitrack files. So the prospect of only spending 2-3 hours on a mix is just impossible. That will often times barely get me past the drum sound! So for us mere mortals that are still stuck mixing real instruments, here’s my process for approaching drum mixing.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think it comes down to ear training, lots of repetition (mixes), and focused practice. He's very familiar with the characteristic sound that each frequency zone imparts on a given instrument and has mixed most instruments enough times to know how to achieve a given effect without having to hunt for it.

On top of that, he's probably thinking an order of magnitude higher than that because he would also understand that if he wants to accentuate a given frequency range in an instrument then he can do that by subtracting that frequency from an adjacent instrument. In this sense, I think he's listening closely to the effect that a cut has on every other instrument in a mix - not just the instrument he's subtracting from.

author: Slow Hand

Surprisingly that mix was still accepted with only a single note from the A+R: "+1dB at 812Hz."

Those who heard the mix said it was "avant-garde" and "visionary". "A glimpse of the future" they said.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Nailed it Will. Split mono is a step in my mix prep sequence. Efficient method goes like this:

PT Downmixer stock plugin is the one for this (it collapses stereo channels to mono) - flip the phase of one side in the GUI and save that as your user default. If you insert your Downmixer on a faux stereo track, it’ll immediately silence it, so you can happily split and delete what you don’t need. 

(Check the meters though, sometimes ambience or other subtle stereo info isn’t very audible unless cranked.)

If the stereo track contains slightly panned mono information, pushing/pulling either of the faders in Downmixer will quickly get it to cancel, and you can note how much extra gain you need to add or subtract when level matching in the final step (below). Obviously if it’s deliberately panned info, you can either just leave the track stereo or match the pan position by ear (I prefer to do this because I like mono channels to behave like mono channels, and also half the CPU you’d use on a stereo track).

Finally, use clip gain to add 3dB to the resulting mono channel, and obviously pan it centre. This makes up for the level change according to default pan laws in Tools (-3dB).

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i love this question. i've been doing this for long enough that the cycles of how records sound has changed several times. so every few years i try and take some time to unlearn/relearn.

there's no good short answer, but i'd start with taking some time outside of mixing to just listen to records. whether you've done this before or not, get to know your speakers and your monitoring environment better than before. listen to your favorite records that you know well, and make some tweaks. you don't necessarily have to redo your whole setup, but listen to your speakers in slightly different positions, different settings on the back of the speaker, etc. and really dig into listening and enjoy yourself.

that's usually enough to make me think about mixes very differently (which ultimately means i get better when i re-incorporate most of the things i already know). but if you need more, just try and simplify. start a mixing by just leveling everything. clip gain and leveling and panning. then balance frequencies and compress (via compressor or saturator or limiter or whatever). basically, with fresh ears, go back to basics.

not sure if that will transform you into a new mixer, but that's an outline of an approach i use when i feel like i need a big talent upgrade

author: Slow Hand
content:
One thing I'd add is the importance of matching your output levels so that the dry sound and the compressed sound are the same volume when you bypass the compression. Many compressors have have automatic volume compensation included and others will require you to adjust the makeup gain that comes after the compression.

The reason it's important is because when we're comparing the dry signal to the compressed signal, the louder of the two signals will always feel better to us. It's important to match the volume levels when comparing so that we're not fooling ourself into thinking a louder signal is better and we can hear the compression (or most effects) for what really is.

author: Slow Hand
content:
The fact that you're already being paid for your work is a great indicator. Just keep going and developing your existing relationships.

That feeling of "I don't really know what I'm doing" is normal. It happens to most of us. And that's okay. I think you'll be surprised when you someday realize that a tremendous amount of people have no idea what they're doing; even those who seem in control. You do your best in the moment and then build on what you've learned and you do it even better the next time.

Don't be afraid of failure. The most courageous thing that you can do is to put yourself in a situation where you feel vulnerable. You will fail and you will fail again, and finally you will succeed. Then you will find yourself in a situation where you get to fail at bigger, better things. That's the process of self-actualization.

You should repeatedly strive to put yourself in a position that puts you at the edge of your abilities. That very feeling of being uncomfortable is a sign that you're in the right place. Challenge yourself and go for it. Pushing yourself in this way is the path to growth and achievement.

You're doing great.

author: cian riordan
content:
Making the jump from working on music for local bands to making music for bigger commercial acts was obviously a big move forward. What I realized very quickly is that the process is fundamentally the same with people of all levels. You get in a room, you make a plan, and you execute it. However, when you've got a major label backing you, there's many more resources available, enabling you to spend more time (and money) making the record... although in my experience this can be both a blessing and a curse!

I assisted Eric for a few years and eventually started networking with more local Los Angeles artists and was able to mix and produce their stuff out of Eric's studio. He was very cool about letting me use the space when we weren't working on bigger projects. He set a very high standard and made it clear that anything that left our studio had to sound really, really great. After assisting and working on my own stuff for several years, Eric then hired me as his full-time main engineer and now I'm on call to work on him for any of his projects. This has been amazing in so many ways as I get to work on high-level commercial music and apply all of my own sensibilities to the process – as well as the stuff I've learned from Eric over the years.

Obviously my tale is one in a million and there's not a day that goes my where I don't realize how lucky I am. Now that I've worked full time recording music for almost 8 years, I've realized there are certain things you need to have to be successful:

author: peterlabberton

Assuming these studios are not run by total hacks (and therefore worthy of you not wanting to be involved), you’re most likely going to have to work on lots and lots of stuff you don’t like, for a long time. And that might apply to working in ways you wouldn’t personally choose. But—again, assuming these studios are at least semi-decent—you’ll learn a lot by involving yourself in other peoples’ work flows. Then you can take it or leave it as you see fit in your own work.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
For the second question, the "car test" is a staple mostly because both sonically and psychologically, the car is a great counterbalance to the context and precision of the studio. 

The car is also the place most people used to listen to the most music as a fan. It still is for many, but I say "used to" because a lot of people's #1 music listening environment outside of a studio is the phone/ headphones/ AirPods. 

So my "car test" is now AirPod max headphones walking around my neighborhood in LA or taking the tube in London. 

But the car also has its advantages because it's noisy and imperfect and NOT isolated like the studio and headphones. You can't listen as precisely in a car, which often tells you very quickly whether you can hear the important parts of your song (can you hear the vocal? Does the low end feel good?).

author: BatMeckley
content:
To second matt, most everyone I’ve seen who had a great “come up” started because someone liked a record they did with a small shitty unknown band. My first real big break came from helping out with and swapping songs with a college buddy, who then managed to get a record deal, and I got to come up and help a little bit and meet with their producer. After a brief stint in Australia in another band, like Matt Rad, I relentlessly (but respectfully) kept reaching out to the producer to see if there was any toilets I could clean or any help at all I could give him, or even if he was just available for a quick lunch and could I play him some bands I was working on.  After a couple months he brought me in and taught me melodyne saying “if you get good at this you’re going to own a house someday”. 

This post is coming from inside the house. 

I think the mistake a lot of people make is they reach out hoping that someone can help them, and not with the intent of how they can help the person they’re reaching out to. I never planned to be Vocal Producer to the Stars ™️ but it turned out it was a job that needed to be done that other people didn’t want to do, and I started to get passed from big name producer to bigger name producer, and then I got enough clout to actually be the middle sized name producer. But it starts with going “hey, what do YOU need” and not “hey can you help ME”

author: cian riordan
content: Hi Rae, these are awesome headphones but -- like any closed back headphone -- it's going to be hard to get a real sense of how things are going translate in the real world..  especially when it comes to low end. Everything on headphones is going to sound clear and direct, when that may not be the case coming through speakers. Checking stuff on some decent monitors in a decent room -- or even in your car --  is always the best way to know if things sound off or not. If you're stuck with headphones, something open back like a Sennheiser 600 will give you a less-hyped, more honest picture of your mix. They're also much less fatiguing to work on for long periods of time! But even to this day with my nice setup, I'm always checking the low end in different places... In my car, I'll know within 10 seconds of listening if things are where they're supposed to be or not.

author: cian riordan
content:
3) Not all manufacturers are created equal. With vinyl pressing plants months behind on their bookings, there are many budget plants that seem to be doing things for cheaper and quicker. You get what you pay for. QRP in Kansas are the best in the business. RTI in CA used to be the gold standard, but they dogged me real hard on a project about 10 years ago and never made things right. Even Doug Sax had to step in to set them straight.

The short of it is, if someone is venturing down the path of manufacturing vinyl for their project — *especially* if it’s self funded — they have to ask what they’re really looking to achieve. If they want a high-quality, analog preservation of their record for all to enjoy, then they need to be prepared to spend some real coin to achieve good results. If they just want a physical item to sell at shows and toss in a download code — that’s OK too — but it will still be pricey, and probably won’t sound great if you do it on the cheap. Just my $0.02.

author: cian riordan
content: I don't work in it a ton, but yeah, the game is won in the low end. It's usually a matter of building up the low end  first and bringing the mix to the brink of crapping out whatever master chain you have without completely falling apart. Then trying to shoe horn in the other elements with aggressive & drastic scooping to maintain the gain structure you've got going with the 808s. Like Jon says often, it's usually about turning things down to gain headroom, and then making it up with low end boosts or high cuts. It's so impressive when it's done right -- shoutout to J.C. -- him and Ali are the best in the game IMHO.

author: ALXCPH
content:
1) always, always, always if possible communicate with the client. Some peeps might want you to do it from the ground up, others might just want the sound of their demo “but better”. It really depends and has no standard. 

2) starting off loud gives you less work, trying to get a finished mix loud without Changing the Sound of it. (Lets you make more “informed” decisions when building a mix if a certain loudness or Sound is your end goal). 

Ps. Mixing for real clients in a real world is never perfect and how it is imagined. Demoitis, deadlines, budgets, ego’s and so on. It’s all just about finding the best way to consistently get results. Because that’s why people hire you.

author: Slow Hand
content:
If your position as a studio runner is paying dividends and you can sustain the lifestyle and afford to go without compensation then continue down that path. It sounds like you're in a position where people may not be giving you the time of day. At this point what a potential mentor figure will be seeking from you is an assurance that you are committed to the path and that their effort will not be wasted on someone who is not committed. 

Considering your position, right now I would recommend adopting an attitude of A) respectful persistence when asking others for insight and help B) private study and a self-starting attitude to make things happen for yourself without their assistance C) actively seeking opportunities to assist, contribute, and be of help to others and D) building your own network of creative collaborators with whom you can continue to create and experiment together.

author: cian riordan
content: It's really just to give you some headroom for processing. Say you have a kick drum thats showing up at 0dBFS (or super hot and limited, or whatever) then you have no room to boost low end without distorting. So turning everything down -6 (or -12 or -3, whatever you want) just gives your processing chain a chance to not fuck things up.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man. 85 percent of the tracks I’d get would require an hour of trying to line up the song PROPERLY to the grid. It’s not as easy as lining a kick to the grid as half you guys are using kick samples that have space before the transient.  When I’m out here nudging and stretching vocals at 1/1000th of second resolutions, which can dramatically change the pocket and vibe, it’s a kick in the teeth then if the whole track ends up being a tenth of a second off. 

The trick I came up with was putting four low frequency Square wave bursts maybe an 1/8th note long each at the beginning or end of each song. That means at no matter the master bus processing (or worse the mp3 meta data at the beginning pushing the song back) you can recalibrate EXACTLY the track back on to the grid. In that case, once you’ve figured that bit out, slap whatever you want on the bus. The square wave trick is how we were able to prove how logic or ableton was bouncing out of time even when a ton of people didn’t hear it or notice.

author: chrissorem
content: Strange I find most people hearing tuning/intonation better with a bass element in the mix. If I’m tuning multiple vocals, I tune the lead and mute other melodic instruments that might be distracting. Then tune  doubles to the lead, tune  the harmony with the lead, tune the  doubled harmonies to the tuned harmony and so on. I try to move fast not worrying about it being perfect and I then solo all the vocals together the see how they feel or put them back in the mix. As I’m working on the song if something feels off I’ll scope it out then. For me It’s very easy to get into a hyper tuning mode where everything sounds like it needs tuned if I obsess over it. I find it better to do a broad stroke pass and fine tune things as needed

author: cian riordan
content:
So! @BoozleBAM! I took a gander and you’re in pretty good shape! I think you’re going to hit some sonic limitations with the quality of your signal path and the cymbals you are using, but the drums sound pretty good and the space you’re in isn’t terrible. Some notes:
- Your cymbal mic'ing approach might be a little overly comprehensive. Its nice to have spot mics on each cymbal, but might be worth trying a more traditional overhead approach. It’ll help get a more natural image of the kit and will likely free up some microphones for other spot positions on the drum set or in the room.
- Your kick drum sounds like a basketball. Theres a few things you can do with tuning, but I would firsttry having some dampening inside. If you like them sounding wide open, then consider taping some felt or paper towels to the inside of the drum shell, at least half way around the interior circumference of the shell. It’ll help quash that bouncing basketball sound.
- Your snare sounds beefy! Obviously, its going to be song and arrangement dependent, but on its own it sounds like you could voice it a little higher to get it to crack a little more.
- If you free up some mics by simplifying your cymbal setup, consider having a mic at the ‘crotch’ position… picking up the center of the kit. It can be useful for anchoring the mono signal of the drums and gives you something nice to potentially squash or distort down the road.
- Your room mics sound pretty good with the right EQing!

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is a constant in record making. Balancing your own thoughts with those of your client or collaborators. 

Cian is right on of course, but I’d encourage you not to think of it as binary. Almost always, there’s a version of their note that makes the song better, and it’s your job to hear it. 

In the end, it’s their record tho, and they’re the ones who will be playing it out, selling it, promoting it however they can… so they’re the ones who *need* to be happy with it in the end. 

My longtime producer & collaborator Jon Kaplan used to say “it’s your record, you can be wrong if you want to.” I give that to artists I work with now. Going in I tell them I’m going to treat you like an equal, until you tell me it’s your record and you can be wrong if you want to. 

Honestly that one idea has eased the tension on so many occasions for me.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pick a tool and push it really hard. See what happens.
Use a tool somewhere it's not supposed to be used.
Ask where the trend is for an instrument and go in the opposite direction. See where that takes you.
Invert your balances.
Go minimal. Strip it away.
Go maximal. Keep adding.
Play with dramatic perspective.
Do three fast mixes and each time it has to be radically different from the previous mix.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
1. Sing a lot every day. If you don't, no other advice matters. Sing songs you like, sing in the shower, sing because you're now a singer. IN ADDITION TO THIS:

2. Hire a decent vocal coach and do a few vocal lessons (even a single lesson with a great teacher is important). You will get someone to teach you in-person how to breathe properly (that's the power source for the instrument you're learning). ALSO, you'll come away with a recording of a vocal warm up (somewhere between 5-20 minutes usually). YOU WILL THEN:

3. Start EVERY day with vocal warm ups.

4. Do whatever else you want to do that gets you singing a lot. Make it fun. I like learning songs, doing a voice memo every time I sing, and occasionally listening back. I sing bob dylan songs for my girlfriend. I record tons of vocals for songs I'm working on. Etc

author: peterlabberton
content: Harsh midrange is my least favorite thing and I spend a lot of effort fighting it. Regardless of whether I’m mixing something I engineered/produced, or something from someone else, I usually start by muting most things and building the song back gradually. As I piece things back in I always have an ear out for resonant pokey stuff and just try to address it ASAP. That’s either through using spectral shaper (very new to me but awesome) or soothe, or just notching stuff with an EQ. I personally avoid doing any of this on the mix bus—if I’m doing it on busses it’ll be some kind of subgroup. Once things are nice and clean, you can boost a lot to get clarity/aggression/etc. etc.. I will say since you mentioned working late at night, I feel getting a decent volume out of my monitors is pretty revealing for this. I don’t mix all that loud, but I definitely have a decent level going. My goal is always to be able to crank things and not have harsh stuff poking at my eardrums!

author: Slow Hand
content: When I make stems for people, I usually deliver them in sub folders to make it easier for the recipient to orient themselves: Folder 1 = *Drums*, Folder 2 = *Harmonic Instruments*, Folder 3 = *SFX*, Folder 4 = *Vocals*, etc. This way they can import the drums as a group and arrange, route, and edit them before they import the next class of instruments.

author: cian riordan
content:
1) Yes! All MPDI-4 mic pres. Signal chain would have been Mic -> Pre -> UTA Console Line In -> Pro Tools.

2) I’m pretty sure this would’ve been a Frankenstein. Most likely Eric’s Sonor birch kick drum with a Remo Black Dot on it. Almost certainly Vistalite toms… and this sounds like a Bell Brass snare.

3) Room mics are placed probably 20 feet away, spaced wide, pointed at the kit. Eric would always point the room mics away from the drums with the cardioid null towards the drum kit, but I found I got more direct, punchy sounds with it facing the drums. Chamber mics would’ve been a foot apart, pointed 45 degs out… sort of intentionally phasey to make them wider.

4) Yeah, you’re onto it. The overheads are intentionally wide and close to the cymbals. The mono mic and close mics are doing the heavy lifting with the drums and the L/R OHs are almost just cymbal spot mics with some kit stereo information peppered in.

5) Saturation is a combination of driving the UTA pres, clipping the line input of the console, and trimming things back with the faders. Might’ve been an LA-2a on the snare with no compression, just crapping out the tubes.

Sorry wish I woulda taken pictures of this session. Dave Elitch was the drummer and he’s a fucking monster.

author: BatMeckley
content:
No, definitely don’t. Please. For the love of God. Don’t. 

Master bus processing to this day still suffers from poor delay compensation, across a variety of daws. You’ll be sending him a 2 track that does not line up with your session, and the ensuing vocal you get back will not line up with what you’ve recorded. Pocket will be off. 

This has been THE SINGLE biggest nightmare in my career as a vocal producer. Please. If at all possible, leave the master off. 

(Unless you do the square wave trick at the end that will allow him to precisely align the files)

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love my dear friend @BatMeckley but I think he's wrong here. Just send the instrumental how it sounds the best, and have them send you a bounced ref along with the vocal. I ask them to send me the session too as I have Pro Tools, Logic, and Ableton and can play with their processing and do a new bounce if need be.

If a vocal bounce comes back with some delay uncompensated or otherwise off the grid, lining up the vocal will NOT take you an hour. You simply line up the ref to your session and the vocal to the ref (the latter is 99% of time already done since they're bouncing from the same session). This takes a few minutes max and I've done it dozens of times. Nudge and flip some phase and you're within a couple samples. You're fine.

author: Will Melones
content:
Are the sides in phase? Two ways I’d consider approaching this.

1. Put a multi-mono Trim plugin on the track. Unlink the channels. Tweak the gain on one channel until they match.

OR

2. Create two mono tracks and ctrl-drag the stereo clip onto them. Clip gain, nudge, nip, and tuck as needed. Then ctrl-drag the two mono clips back onto the stereo track.

author: LAPhill
content:
There are plenty of times that I’ll use a high pass on or above the fundamental frequency, depending on context. If I have 5 instruments all playing the same note, then chances are some of them want to live in different parts of the frequency range (maybe strummy guitars are more about the transients and first harmonics, for example). 

As everyone’s saying, if it sounds good it is good, but I wouldn’t overthink the note-to-frequency thing too much.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Maybe this is a hot take, but I believe everyone is actually self-taught. We each have unique learning styles- some are better with visual examples, some auditory, some complete fucking animals read the manual, 
Some like no examples at all and just want to experiment. 

Modern music making is a playground, and doing things wrong often engenders creativity.   Technique is teachable, but artistry is only cultivated. 

Curiosity and tenacity are the only skills required. Everything else is a google search away.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yes. “My kid wants to make music, how do I get them started?” Is a question we all get.

My answer is always- pick an instrument that excites them, and get them into something local with other kids. The community aspect of music can’t be overstated.

author: cian riordan
content:
I started getting serious about recording while I was in college (studying chemistry). I was playing bass in a band at the time and I was the only one that had any sort of decent recording equipment. I found myself being the guy recording all of the band's demos before we went into a 'proper studio'. Eventually, we realized my demos were sounding better than the ones we paid other people to record! Meanwhile, I started assisting (for free) at a local small recording studio and met a really great mentor. The studio was small and its business was mostly weekend warrior type stuff – nobody really notable. That being said, it was a working studio – and booked almost 6-7 days a week. The producer was the big fish in the small pond and had a great repeat clientele. Most of the music was not my cup of tea – but this proved to be a good thing as I was exposed to all sorts of different styles and it allowed me to be comfortable in genres of music which I normally wouldn't gravitate towards. It just made me comfortable around music and musicians in general.

Once I graduated and decided I wasn't going to use my chemistry degree, I ended up helping the producer build a bigger studio complex from the ground up. I learned an insane amount of stuff during this period – whether it was researching which Pro Tools system we would need to helping design the wiring layout to actually implementing it all. Ultimately, after months of hard work (and lots of borrowed money) the studio was complete and it was ready for business. I worked here for 2 years or so until I got introduced to Eric Valentine through former Street To Nowhere guitarist Matt Radosevich in Los Angeles. He needed a new full-time assistant and so I hopped at the opportunity and moved to LA – leaving behind the studio and crew I helped build (they're still going today and they're doing great).

author: Zack Hames
content:
This has been my experience;

Mixing was always guess and check. It was also a lot of mixing in compensations. Example: when the vocal is barely too loud it’s actually perfect. When the low end is just barely too thin it’s actually perfect. 

To me, the right monitoring is whatever you can mix 100% intuitively and then be satisfied far more often than not when listening on other systems. 

So, In short:

-are you able to mix intuitively and not be shocked by what the mix sounds like outside of the studio?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
One thing that’s important when getting acclimated is listening to a LOT of music. If the monitoring is truly good, when you listen to your favorite records you’ll be able to hear things in a fresh way, sometimes details you’ve never noticed will jump out.  

And then when you go back to your record you should be able to hear the distance between the two things fairly quickly. Things like low end, transient response, reverb tails, midrange detail (or lack thereof if you make metal) etc. 

Sometimes just the fact that you can *hear* things makes you feel like it sounds good, but the key is to know what “good” is for each case.

author: Adam Thein
content:
I'm going to take a stab but it's a little picky on the terminology and it's long-winded:

Usually working with a mixer is like driving down a one way street in terms of file swapping.  You typically bring in a mixer when your song and production is fully complete, you've made it the best version of itself you could reach on your own but still want to bring in someone with more experience to help you take it to that next level of polish.  So typically in this version of a client/mixer relationship you probably wouldn't ever ask for the multitrack post-edit without some sort of unique circumstance that you'd be communicating with them directly.

It sounds to me in your other conversations here that in your case, the mixer is really filling a engineering/additional production role in your project.  They are taking files of yours before they can see the entire picture of the song and helping shape the tones, doing the editing, and managing the files for you as you submit more pieces to them over time.  In this type of working relationship files are typically shared in a two way street style.  You both are collaborating and working together toward the finish line.  This role is not something I would call a mixer though - they may still do your final mixes but they are also acting as an engineer or even producer.

I know this is being a little semantic but I think it's important because the context changes how you can describe it as customary or not.

As always, you'll need to chat directly to them and explain a bit why you want to get those edited multitracks back.  My first assumption sadly if I were in your buddy's shoes is that you weren't happy with the work and wanted to send those files to someone else.  So if that's the case, let them know early, and if that's not the case, let them know why you want the files.

author: cian riordan
content: First I'll think about what the tonal impact will be. There are particular compressors that automatically suck low or high end out of the signal... and for something like bass that can occupy a very crucial part of the low end, that could prove problematic. Usually if I'm compressing bass, it's to bring out the sustain of the low end. So I'll typically set the release & the makeup gain first first to a place where I like how the low end is holding out, then dial in the attack to taste (usually on the medium-to-slow side). Grabby compression on bass can be fun in very specific instances, but I often find it distracting and fatiguing.

author: Rollmottle
content: @kidcutler hit all the practical cons...running all the infrastructure to stand up a new structure is pricey. also, once you get the city or county involved, they'll want their cut and re-assess the property to include the new building for an updated tax basis. i would think about long term...would you purpose build a space that is specifically a studio? or would you just build a structure and make a studio inside? for re-sale, if it's a purpose-built studio, that certainly narrows the audience who would find a purpose-built studio a value-add to the purchase. if it's just a building that can be turned back into an ADU or garage easily, then that's an easier thing for most buyers to wrap their head around and probably a value-add. if you can build it as an ADU or garage, this might also change the way it's assessed. depending on the laws where you live, you might be able to get away with a building up to a certain square footage for "free." the way in which the building is classified might also make a difference. here in Glendale, CA, they've really loosened the ADU laws to encourage people to build to relieve pressure on a short-supply rental market. if you stay under a certain square footage, your tax basis does not change. i think it's a generally a great idea if you have the $$$$$$ and patience. if this is what you'll be doing for, well, your life, then it seems like a worthy investment to make.

author: Rollmottle
content:
> Like compressing a signal for it to be "even" (not that I would use a compressor for that) vs. using something like clip gain to make the signal even.

why wouldn't you use a compressor for that? that's what...they do?....clip gaining has the same effect, it's just manual and theoretically offers you more fine-grained control that a compressor wouldn't get you. you are still reducing the dynamic range in either scenario. you can draw volume automation on a signal that is identical to a theoretically transparent compressor's settings and the effect, sound, and dynamic range reduction should be exactly the same.

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is a good question.

The short answer is yes and no.  The phase interaction is more dramatic and obvious the closer in level the two sources are. So if you turn one of them WAY louder than the other, even if they're phasing out, it will be way less obvious. If the frequencies (usually the low end) that are fighting phase wise are the exact same volume, it will be super obvious that htey are phasing out.

author: Slow Hand
content:
A strong second on this. I'm not someone who interacts with many kids on a regular basis, but I've felt a similar openness and lack of inhibition during my experiences doing improv comedy. It has so much in common with what we observe in children. Finding your way back to that state of non-judgement is such a worthy pursuit.

Improv education places such an emphasis on not being precious about things, accepting what's happening in front of you, and not overthinking. Most of all, the biggest lessons were always about *listening*: Listening to your partners, listening to their intent, and listening to the audience. There is no time to plan. You just do.

I did it for two years and it was one of the most rewarding experiences of my life. The improv mindset really enriches everything else in your life once you open yourself up to it.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I really like mono reverbs for:

1. Vocal verb. It can just give the vocal it's own little space instead of spreading it out into the rest of everything in the sides. Just has a different feel, similar to "Mono drums" iMO.

2. Panning a reverb hard to one side, opposite of a dry signal. I.E. Electric guitar or synth.

Also, I use mono -> stereo reverbs a lot because when I was learning, I used the Lexicon PCM-70 a lot which was mono input. It also just made sense to me...not sure it matters a whole lot though ultimately. That is an aside to your question.

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Other ideas:**

Call and response between the players.
Give the players big unison hits that they can land on together.
Everybody takes a big rest.
Everybody takes a big rest except one player.
Everybody plays the melody in unison.
Hocket the melody between players.
Swap roles among the players (Guitar plays like a drummer, drummer plays melodically, bassist sings).
Counterpoint.
Play dynamically.
Dynamics that rise or fall over two or more bars.

author: LAPhill
content:
Noah covered a lot, but a few (also stream of consciousness) thoughts to add:

There is no formula to when to take the leap. It's helpful to have some money in the bank, because it's going to take awhile for things to start happening. The more connections you have, the more in-roads you've made, the easier it will be to drum up work in music and keep the lights on. The less responsibilities and overhead you have, the easier the beginning stages of freelance life will be.

Don't think about your music career in terms of the same metrics as your day job, you're burnt out on it for a reason. So instead of "am I making what I made before," think "can I survive on this for now?" and if not, "what will get me to a place that I can afford to pursue this dream?"

Any music job can be a boon for your career, and chances are you don't know where the opportunities will come from. The Beatles became the Beatles by playing cover songs at shady clubs, honing their sound and learning to play with each other. For someone else, that would've been a mindless, thankless gig with no upside. When they started playing better gigs, they were ready and stood out because of it.

How you do anything is how you do everything - if you're an intern at a studio cleaning up trash, you may be around huge artists and engineers. If they see you as dependable, friendly, going above-and-beyond, there's a tiny chance that a life-changing opportunity could emerge. Likewise, if they see you doing a sloppy job, that's how they're going to assume you'd be in the room, too.

author: LAPhill
content: A car is also an investment on being able to get to gigs, drinks with clients, etc. Depending on where you live, it's pretty much a necessity for work. Ubers add up quick, and they don't like it when you put a whole drum set in the back seat.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@BoozleBAM it's worth adding that it's fun to realize that the drum set is just that: a set of drums. The idea that one person plays all the drums in one coordinated set all at once is a pretty narrow part of the whole of drumming, percussion, rhythm, etc. 

There are SO many cool and interesting ways to make "drums" happens.

I would spend some time with some of these records that people are sharing, and thinking about ALL the rhythmic components, both separately and together. 

Take some time, be patient, and try to expand your brain in how you think about this stuff. Lots of good insight from people here and some amazing trails for you to follow. I'm excited for you!

author: Zack Hames
content:
Try:
-compression on drum bus first before individual mics. I find compressing rooms on their own makes them sound small not big

-time delay rooms to make the room seem larger. This is a big albini trick 

-don’t be afraid to EQ the shit out of kick drum mics 

-don’t be afraid to add a lot of low end to the snare 

-transient designers on close mics can make shit punchy

author: BatMeckley
content:
Not going to put myself in the “massively talented” category (I’ll let cian do that for me) but I do have a decent clutch of nice gear, and I’ve made records that sound like me at my place as well as completely remote spots with borrowed gear and shitty conversion. I think the main thing is speed. I’m going to keep turning the knobs untill it sounds like I want it to, and with today’s tech you can pretty much do it with anything. It’s just that with the gear I’ve chosen for myself, I get the results I want quicker. It’s not that I CANT fight the gear, it’s just that I’d rather not if I can help it. 

As someone who just switched back to a trackball after trying to work on a trackpad for two years because of the tenths of a second of latency, there’s a real creative upside to immediacy. 

Then again, there’s something really inspiring about learning new gear that might break you out of stagnant patterns of doing things.

author: Eric Martin
content:
room tone and proximity effect are why.

If you have a great sounding room you can back off the mic and you’ll introduce room tone, or the sound of the room into the mic’d bleed.

If you have a dead room you can back off with this happening less, there will still be some sound there, but less.

A lot of studio mics are used with the Cardioid polar pattern depending on the source and what sound you need for the recording, getting closer to the mic can introduce more low end from what’s know as proximity effect, this can exaggerate the way the lows are heard from the source on a record.

If you find yourself EQing out low end, maybe back off the microphone a bit and experiment with how far and hear how much room gets introduce as you add more preamp gain when you do this.

It’s a choice, and a decision, learn why you like it and where.

Omni mics have little to no proximity effect, figure 8 also have some proximity effect, use this to your advantage.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@Zack Hames yes! Play with short delays and short verbs and slaps with low pass eq. H3000 has some great stereoizing chorus type effects too. 

I just did a super dry vocal that had delay and verb like this. I used waves supertap with left and right slightly different but super short delay times. Almost phasing. Barely blended in at -20dB. Then I used Valhalla Vintage Verb on the small ambience setting at like 4%. It widens the vocal and gives it space without sounding at all "wet"

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I usually get a backbeat or 4 on the floor going, even if it's subtle. But I've had a lot of great songs written to just that, then drums are built around it later. tbh if you have that and you're having trouble getting drums to work later, it's usually not because you didn't get proper drums in there. If the song is great and there's a basic beat, you're pretty much set. a simple backbeat goes a long way.

As I've said before, I think the two essential parts of a song are not actually piano/vocal or guitar/vocal but instead beat/vocal. chords are obviously important, usually. But melody against rhythm is primarily what people move to and remember. if you can sing and clap it, you've probably got something.

author: cian riordan
content: I think starting out with a modern compressor with all the parameters available to you will be more helpful in learning the concept. That way you can really understand the idea of a threshold, different attack/release combinations, and and compression ratios. Once you can start to understand what you're hearing, then you can apply that to other compressors that might have more fixed variables (LA2a, etc). I've always found overdoing it when you're first getting the settings will help you understand whats going on.

author: Adam Thein
content:
My advice here - I have not seen the issue I mentioned today if I'm batching out groups of stems.  For example - if I print a group of stems on THE SAME RENDER then they tend to sum with each other correctly/sample accurately.  It seems in my case to be if I'm printing stems one at a time, then one print may sometimes be offset 1 sample.  So if you are printing multitrack drums, try and print them together, or at the very least, load them into another DAW or a clean session and make sure they are adding back up like you expected ESPECIALLY for parallel processing.

The main takeaway here should be if you are sending files to another person to work on them you should always check your work so what goes out is what you expected to have go out!

author: cian riordan
content: There's some standards that are useful -- outs over ins, normalling strategy... that type of stuff. Really comes down to what you're trying to achieve. If you're operating a big tracking studio, then you want that workflow in mind: tie lines normalled to mic pres, mic outs normalled to A/D inputs, D/A outs normalled to monitor controller & headphone boxes, etc. If you're in a mixing room (like me), I have things setup so outboard gear is accessible via hardware inserts through patchbay normalization. As for labelling, I've been using my own spreadsheet system that I find more useful than patchbay labelling software. Here's an example of my setup from last year:

author: Slow Hand
content:
What are you doing for chords? A common pitfall of static arrangements is getting locked into the same four bar chord loop. Sometimes you've got to break out of that. Start there, even if it's as simple as telling a different story with your chords over eight bars versus four bars.

Play with the harmonic rhythm of your chord changes. Some very basic examples:
1. Instead of a single chord every measure, alternate between one chord per measure and two chords per measure.
2. Hold on a single chord for six measures and then do a cadence with a quick succession of chords on bars seven and eight.
3. Take your progression and play it at half the speed (a four bar progression becomes an eight bar progression).

I know you said you're just making beats right now, but chords or a melody are going to inform and motivate your "players" and show them what to do. There needs to be some "meat" to the song for them to react to. If you don't like the melody you can mute it later. But give your "players" something to react to.

author: cian riordan
content: Your results will almost always be attributed to your skills! In this case, while I'd focus my attention on getting some reps in on various mixing projects, there's certainly room to grow in your equipment stable. Headphones are a great starting point and will likely continue to be useful down the road, but mixing on speakers helps you make things translate better to the real world (car & home stereos, public spaces, etc). So a pair of decent entry level monitors would be my next purchase. It will also prove useful for collaborating with other folks down the road as you can all hear the same thing from the same source.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Of course depends on the tempo, part, sound of the drums, aesthetic of the track - but a few things that have worked in different scenarios for me:

Create the impression of some distance to walls by sending snare (start there, maybe add other mics) to a short stereo delay. Often something like 90ms on one side, 120ms on the other. Feel it out on one side, then add some time to the other.

Try adding some fake distance to your existing room mics with a simple delay with no feedback (there’s a Steve Albini drum video on YouTube where he demonstrates this). You can delay both sides equally, or solo one side, delay it til it feels good/sounds cool, then do the other. Anything from 12ms-around 23 seems to work. From there things start to become more like a slap, but than can be cool too.

Smash up your existing rooms a bit, or a lot. Omnipressor, Devil Loc, UAD Zener, decapitator, Rough Rider (free), Arousor/Distressor in nuke, Lo-Fi. 

Send to a gated verb - Cian shared a drum session a while back with a short VintageVerb preset that’s often useful. RMX16 Non-Lins can be good too, although it’s easy to bring things into 80s territory this way.

Send to a short room verb like ocean way, SP2016, Pro-R, Valhalla Room, Raum. Sometimes from close mics, sometimes from overheads, sometimes just slapping it straight on room mics. A little distortion (Decapitator, Devil Loc) after is often helpful.

With all of these solutions, the thing that seems to help them gel with the rest of the real kit is drum bus processing - compression and/or saturation.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Also with tracking my mindset is

Always a L and R for rthyms or main guitar. And then quads for emphasis and I’ll go insane with different layers with different octaves. On impactful parts that need some lift (natural automation as I jokingly call it) I’ll stack a distorted l/r octave down on some hits with like a pitch pedal or octave fuzz, but it’s never to stand out or be heard it’s just like when I need the rthyms to feel larger than the previous section.


Quads of the same octave help reinforce the tone than trying to be a whole other part sonically

author: BatMeckley
content:
More often than not it seems the main songwriter demos the song. Maybe a drum loop, maybe some programmed drums. Plays guitar and/or keys and sings.

Drummer then plays along to the in time demo. This will be the keeper drums. 

Band instruments then re-played, layered on top of the keeper drums. 

Then vocals. 

Then whatever little extra schmutz you want to add. 

Then you clear some space on the wall for the inevitable awards and plaques.

author: cian riordan
content: It's replicating the original 1073 preamp gain knob, which had a few off switches for utility purposes. The old 80 series consoles often had a universal phantom power strapped across all the channels – the off position was a quick way to kill phantom if you needed to hot patch a mic. Also just a quick way to kill signal to a channel if there was a feedback spike or something.

author: cian riordan
content: No difference sonically, just all workflow, resource management, etc. Sends harken to a time when outboard effects were limited, so it made sense to send things to a plate so you didn't have to have 20 giant EMT plates in your studio to put on each track you wanted reverb on. Nowadays, in the computer, it's less important and just comes down to workflow. Sometimes some mixes call for a more uniform reverb to tie tracks together... in this case putting it on a send makes more sense. But there's no rules anymore, and if you don't like that workflow, then fuck it. Do it your way. There's no right or wrong on this.

content: It may be worth moving the location of both the mic and the performer. author: peterlabberton
content: Annoying answer, but, it depends. (Ha! Stock answer for almost everything.) If the performance is uneven and really needs to be smoothed out, I might go for an 1176 at like 8:1 and catch loud parts. Then I might do a parallel comp (dbx 160, often), for more sustain and maybe snappiness. If certain notes are really poking out against others, as is often the case, I’ll ruthlessly eq them so they are balanced with Pro-Q3, instead of trying to solve that with more compression.

author: peterlabberton
content: Oh, echoing @cian riordan , the release feels especially important to me on bass gtr. I feel like it’s one of the few instances where I would regularly go with a longer release (I’m usually a big fast release dude). This would be if the bass is doing mostly whole notes, to get it to fill more of the measure. If I’m being specific about attack time... I’m usually (like almost always) getting the punch totally from the kick, so a faster attack usually feels pretty good to me, at least for the compressor not in parallel. And yes to the tonal change—I feel like usually I end up wanting to cut low end and add some kind of aggression, so compressors that go in that direction work well for me.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Honestly I just use Steven slate trigger 2. There may be better ones.

If you don’t have one, you can make a beat map (ala pro tools) this way you can make your session grid line up to the drum performance itself. author: cian riordan
content:
Now that the basics are happening — kick and snare are really standing on their own two feet and in a place to drive the song — I’ll start bringing in other instruments in the mix and getting a sense of how things are adding up. Usually starting with bass, guitars, keys and finally vocals. Some people do vocals first — that’s never worked for me. Once you have a balance of the track, you can start really incorporating some of the overheads and room mics to give the drums more dimension and flavor. If the engineer really fucked the dog with the recording — or the room just sounds bad — I won’t spend too much time making them work… I’ll just get to manufacturing something that sounds cool. This could be leaning into a spring reverb, or a fun delay, or using other creative reverbs to get the drums have the space you want. I’m a big fan of un-natural sounding drums… distorted spring reverb panned hard left with a slap panned hard right? Why not! If someone serves you shit, shovel them ice cream.

Toms will literally be the last thing I work on. It’s just a matter of seeing what’s missing from the overall picture and filling in the blanks with the spot mics. I don’t like to trim the regions because I might find that when I’m gating, some of the bleed sounds good from the track. Sometimes, if the engineer did their job, the multi-mic recording will be really complete and will need the tom mics for the overall sound… so no gating at all. Again, all depends on what you’re working with.

Once I move on with the rest of my mix, I’ll find myself doing EQ moves on the drum buss and treating it more like one instrument to get other things happening in the mix… only doing small tweaks to the individual sounds.

I hope this all makes sense?

author: Slow Hand
content:
Neat question. If you're mixing in two channels (L/R) the headroom should be the same no matter where you pan it (with some caveats which we'll get to). If you have a kick drum panned dead center coming in at -6dB on your digital meter it's going to be coming in at -6 in both the L channel and -6 in the R channel. Each channel has it's own independent headroom that doesn't affect the other (until we add a limiter with linked channels), so let's simplify things a bit and mute the R channel for now:

Now you have your L channel with the kick panned "center" and the R channel is muted.  If you were to pan this kick to the hard left it would not affect the volume of the L channel at all. That's because the panning effect is created by subtracting gain from the R channel only. Making the kick sound like it's leaning to the left.

Now there's one big element I've left out so far, and that's *pan law*. Ableton Live has a -3dB pan law. This means that sounds panned to the center are reduced by 3dB. Because if a sound is being played at the same volume by both the L and R channels then their voltage will combine to create a sound that is louder than intended. So all DAWs and mixers compensate for this added loudness by turning down the gain of sounds as they are panned closer to the center (and shared between both speakers).

Since all modern DAWs and mixers have pan laws implemented, what happens when you now pan the kick hard left is that it ends up becoming 3dB louder than it was when it was panned in the center, because it is no longer being turned down by the pan law when it’s centered.

author: David Fuller
content:
To go into more detail... Unbalanced signaling like a guitar or a speaker input from an amplifier just has a signal lead (hot) and a common (ground). Speaker cables in particular do not use the common as shielding where unbalanced line level (like consumer RCA) and instrument level cables do. 
Balanced signaling like mics and pro audio line level equipment requires a "hot" signal, a "cold" signal (either polarity inverted hot or just nothing but with the same source impedance), and a common (ground/shield). At the receiving end of the connection, there is what's called a differential amplifier. Short version, a differential amp polarity inverts cold and combines it with hot, thereby reducing common mode noise by cancellation (and also some distortion, but we'll get back to that later).

author: Slow Hand
content:
Perhaps I can address your issue at the source with how you have your Ableton compressor set up:

You're saying that you cannot get your 808 to duck low enough each time the kick hits. The first thing that stands out to me is that you're using a soft ratio. You need to crank that ratio up to at *least* a 4:1 ratio, but you might be even better off with an 8:1 or higher ratio. You need a high ratio to get the deeper ducking effect that it seems you're seeking.

Using a soft ratio will never get you a big duck unless you have the threshold pulled all of the way down. And even then it's probably going to have issues recovering correctly after each duck.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Use EQs with knobs and no frequency analyzer. Your brain will always defer to what you see over what you hear, and if you’re drawing lines and looking at analyzers you’re essentially “seeing” the sound as much as hearing it. Which ultimately is really useful for getting good results and solving problems quickly. But, if you want to focus on what you’re hearing, you have to minimize the visual activity. 
Using a 1073 style eq, your brain will start to connect sounds with numbers, and so you’ll hear something and start thinking “snare needs more 200 and less 600” or whatever, and then you’ll start to associate numbers with abstract concepts like “brightness” or “punch.” 

And it will be your ears not your eyes doing the work 🙌🏻

@Zack Hames is right- the more you do it the better you get at it, and there’s no substitute for time.

author: Adam Thein
content:
You mentioned it already but one of the only consistent rituals for me is trying to split up the "mix assistant" type work on a different day if possible or at the very least with a break that involves leaving the room and doing something completely unrelated for a while.

Other than that pretty typically starting from drums/bass/vocals and trying to fill in around that.  But that's on an ideal day for me - more often it's just getting excited about something I heard, getting an idea, and playing around with the mix a lot.  I'm pretty early on in the journey with mixing relatively but realized I was getting burned out already if I didn't continue experimenting and playing around with a song the way I did when I first got interested in this in the first place.  Usually trying new things on every single mix because I have the luxury of usually not being up against the clock working on indie releases.

content: If you're doing any kind of office or flex space, be very up front about what you'll use the room for. author: oaklandmatt
content:
One of the reasons I think this way is because anytime you EQ something, you are introducing phase shifts around either side of the frequency you're using. I find low end to be particularly sensitive to phase shifts. Phase shifts blur sound slightly, which is particularly bad for the low end instrument that you want to be punchy and full. 

While EQ may boost your overall low end, often times you are losing punch and clarity at the same time.
