author: Adam Thein
content:
When I was doing my deep dive recently - there's a couple great videos put together by Starsky Carr and J3P0 with comparisons.  I think Prophet 5 wins out on raw tone from the oscillators, but the 6 is 90% of that flavor with a much more modern filter.  They added vintage mode a couple years back which really helped it step even closer to the Prophet 5/10, and the modern features like the Arp, Sequencer, and on board effects as well as that very sick analog distortion circuit make it a lot more versatile for sound design (within the Prophet tonescape obviously).

I'm still in the honeymoon phase with mine but I'm glad I went with a P6 personally.  A lot more viable as a performance instrument and it can also get very very very close to the P5/P10 sounds if you keep it dry and keep the filter closed a bit more.

The only thing the P6 doesn't do that the P5/P10 can that I wish it could is the way it does voice allocation in non-unison modes - I believe it always steps through round-robin with voices, whereas the P5/P10 retriggers the same voice for the same key until you move away from that key.  Not a huge deal since you can use Unison 1 voice for basses if you want to retrigger the same voice each time.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Case dependent on song of course but generally 3 phases

1) Clean - clean up obvious issues, noise, excessive low end, overly roomy, overly dynamic (sometimes completely raw like this might have 20-30db or higher swings in dynamic range between sections) clip gain

2) Dynamics and EQ in track context - compress and EQ how you usually would for what's appropriate

3) Stylize - effects, saturation, stylized EQ

Well I’ll kick things off by saying that two years with an artist is a long time and you’re bound to hit some plateaus & frustration points. These kinda of relationships really grow you over time. author: Slow Hand
content:
If it already sounds good to you as is, perhaps you don’t need to worry about  editing it to “perfection”. Follow your intuition here and do what sounds good. 

One can certainly edit tracks into oblivion with certain techniques and before you know it you’ve got a sterile-sounding feel on your record.

I would start by asking yourself “What am I trying to achieve?” and then if you still feel that it needs some editing go for it, rather than working from a technique that you saw someone do and shoe-horning your music into it.

author: Eric Martin
content: keep an eye on average volume also, some instruments might have a very low peak to average where if you record the peaks might not be very high, but the average is, I try to keep faders at zero but perceive the loudness, so drum peaks can be much higher than guitar peaks because drums have a very wide peak to average ratio, distorted guitars peak to average level is generally very low where the peak is not much higher than the average.

author: Eric Martin
content:
I’ve gotten track as to mix where faders at zero would blast you into the next time zone, which is why I always view waveforms at zero so I can visually see if I need to turn the clip gain down or not before even hitting go, I know I know I know, it’s music, listen, but if I turn it down then I can fly through the session with clip gain key commands getting balance with the faders at zero and never touching the mouse until I really need to start manipulating things with EQ and compression.

I always start a mix with just volume and panning, we can get really far with that

author: Nomograph Mastering

content:
Hey. Welcome! 

Based on what you've shared, it sounds like you're early in your journey making records. There are a lot of reasons that an Apollo might be a good investment, but buying them for the converters probably isn't the best use of your money at this stage.

The difference that converters will make (if any) is very very small compared to other factors. Factors like having a good room to listen in, acoustic treatment for the room, and the monitors you're listening through. I would prioritize those and consider converters to be very low priority until you get those other factors working well.

So unless there are other reasons that you'd like to have an Apollo I think you can save your money for the time being.

author: Rollmottle
content:
The buffer has nothing to do with sample rate or fidelity of a given capture. Buffer only matters for the performance of your computer. For setting your buffer, you'll have to find the balance between latency and stability if you're recording. If you're mixing, raise the buffer until your system is stable. 

For sample rate and bit depth, you will be fine working at 48/24.

author: cian riordan
content:
Kick EQ:
- Mostly just scooping out the boxy low mids. Adding low end and a hair of high end. That ~800hz move is to pull out the ‘boing’ inherent in the sound.

author: cian riordan
content:
Snare EQ:
- Just taming a bothersome resonance and adding in a little snap.

author: cian riordan
content:
Cymbals:
- These were honestly the toughest part of the sound. I ended up bussing all your cymbal mics and treating them as a set. I found myself hunting for a place to pull back the high-mid harshness but introduce some of the airy sizzle. The tape machine plugin I used helped a bit with this (Studer A800 with the HF calibration dialed up a bit)
- Also these were the only mics that needed the phase to be flipped! Everything else added up nicely.

author: cian riordan
content:
Rooms:
- Just pulling the muck out. There was some cool, usable low end in there once I scooped out the bad stuff.

author: cian riordan
content:
Whole kit
- I found afterwards that I might have gone a little too overzealous in pulling out high mids, so put a little bit back in and notched out the harshest elements. The low end moves were just finessing I felt needed after having everything focus.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
For me if I were you. I’d have done it like this

1.scratch out the song with programmed drums and focus on making sure the click track is right. Do as many tempo changes and push and pulls till it feels right. Map out the song to where it feels exactly how you want it. Do minimal programming to get the idea’s across you don’t have to go wild with velocities. Since your a drummer you should know what your playing and it’ll make it way easier

2. Track rthym guitars and bass and comp them while you track 

3. Track vocals

Either tune em your self or comp them like crazy whatever makes you happy 

4. Track leads 

5. Track drums 

6. Mix it

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, for pro tools I assign the three extra buttons for each one of the tools, and then chording the top two buttons gives me multitool in the instances that’s useful.  

Then my left hand is on asdfg for fades and moving the boundaries of clips (WAY faster than multi tool to just click in the middle of a region or at the zero crossing of an audio file and hitting A)

After a few days it should become pretty intuitive and automatic. Like anything else, it’ll take a second to adjust, 2 steps back, 3 steps fwd style.

Another perk of using melodyne standalone is assigning the trackball buttons for the note tune, cut notes, note length, and the chords for vibrato and note length tools. Makes melo WAYYYY faster.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When Jon receives a song to mix, there is almost always a lot of compression on the individual stems, especially drums and vocals. So he does more subtle moves to bring out the best in each mix. If you're recording stuff yourself, you will likely want to add a lot of compression to get the same modern, perceived loudness.

The fundamental thing to know is that "compression" simply means "reducing the dynamic range" (aka "compressing" the range of volume of your sound ). This can be achieved with "compressors" as well as "limiters," "saturators," "clippers," "distortion," and a number of other types of effects that do it in different ways (and may add other sonic characteristics to your sound).

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I got locked into 500 series while I was touring (for like 10 years,) and once I got my home studio setup I had everything hard wired, each mic had its own dedicated chain. All so I could work at the speed of my creativity focusing on parts & performance rather than capture & sonics. 

About 5 years in I was fast and savvy enough that I could let the Sonics play a bigger role without sacrificing momentum, so last year I installed a patch bay. Now just grabbing a mic to record takes a little longer, but I can do a lot more fun & creative work on the way in. 

So even if you decided to go 500 series, I’d argue that the modularity isn’t as big of a selling point on a microcosmic level. 

It might be worth thinking about the 500 series like a console, get yourself 8 Avedia Ma5s and do all your eq & compression in the box.

author: Slow Hand
content: Oh cool. Well you may already know then, but it's a nylon string guitar, which is going to sound and play differently than a steel string. Nylon is going to sound more mellow in tone than a jangly/bright steel string. The neck/fingerboards are very different in shape too. If you're not already familiar with nylon string guitar, you may want to lay your hands on it and make sure that it's a sound you're interested in.

If it sounds good and it feels good it is good.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. I'm used to having more control as an MD for artists and not handing it off to another party and having it out of my hands. An important aspect of these live performance mixes would be consistency of level between them all. Don't send the artist out with one track that's super loud and another that's considerably quieter. Like @Rollmottle says, you want the live tracks to be predictable and consistent and whoever is handling the tracks should ensure that they're level-matched relative to each other. You want to do your best to ensure that the live tracks are all reaching the live engineer at a consistent and unwavering level, so that they aren't getting any curveballs from the person running the tracks.

author: Zack Hames
content: I’ve honestly not ever been able to just “get used to” a shitty monitoring situation. I tried to convince myself of that by using the same pair of Yamaha HS80m’s for years, and somehow never liked my mixes. Got new, better monitors and better treatment and my mixes got better. The “just use what you have and get used to it” only goes so far IMO. I don’t think you can get used to messed uneven low end, bad first reflections, poor stereo imaging/center, etc. My ears want to make things sound good, not blindly over-compensate. I find working like that is exhausting.

author: cian riordan
content: Hoo boy... live recording is such an anxiety hole for me. My only takeaway would be focus on isolation and flexibility and less on vibe. You can add that in later, but you can't isolate in post. I'm dealing with a live record at the moment and I can get the instrumentals to sound amazing, but the vocal mics are just bleed central and completely destroy the mix. Try super tight patterns on everything, Beta 58s on vocals if you can, & don't compress anything going into the computer.

author: peterlabberton

So the fact that they’re just monitoring in the room and will naturally balance themselves to some extent—assuming they’re good players and actually listen!—might actually help you a good deal. Also if you can setup so they’re in a circle facing in, or otherwise angle vocal mics away from instruments, do that.

author: Eric Martin
content:
test pressings don’t work that way, the test pressing is to determine if the cut and plating has any problems, if it does all 5 of the pressings will have the same problems in the same spots.

What you need to do is sit and listen with a notepad noting the times of the “problems” you hear, on each pressing, then if all of them have the same issue, then you have a problem with the pressing.

If you know the cutting engineer that’s the best.

My cutting engineer said, “watch sibilance and take all loudness processing off, driver at -18 and you know then you’ll have a decent vinyl master.

author: Slow Hand
content: We listen to most records in 16 bit and that sounds fine. 17 bits is *double* that resolution. 18 bits is *quadruple* that resolution. By using 24 bits we've increased the resolution of the dynamic range 256 times compared to a 16 bit signal. I've never seen any evidence that we can hear the difference between 24bits of audio and 32 bits.

author: Rollmottle

author: Eric Martin
content: I’d echo what’s been said but I’d also add that you should play with the tuning of the batter and reso head to get the sound, you might be surprised to hear that tighter might actually deliver more low tone and overtone to the mic than the puff of air that a too loose head will deliver, I’d also mess with the dampening material, start with less dampening and only dampen what it needs to tame the basketball ping if you get that tone. And let the beater rebound don’t bury the beater, imagine the kick drum is a guitar string and burying the beater is like playing with a piece of foam killing the resonance. play with all these things and you’ll get more low end

author: cian riordan
content:
Process/Theory:
I see lots of people’s previous responses say they begin with getting the overheads to sound great and then start blending in close mics. If the drums were recorded by someone who knew what they were doing, with a good sounding kit, in a nice room — this would be a wonderful way to approach things. However 90% of the time that’s not the case with tracks that come my way. So I’m solving fro two problems — making the drums:
1) The foundational rhythm element. It doesn’t matter how good tonally your drums sound, they need to fill specific duties to carry the rhythm of the song. This is usually problem solving with phase within the elements of the drum set and then mostly getting the kick and snare to sit right around the rest of the instruments. Literally getting the right transients in the right frequency ranges — agnostic of ‘tone’ and ‘vibe’.
2) The sense of space for the mix. The drums are a huge part of this… and the foundation for the aesthetic of a mix. Is it a tight space? Big verby snare? This is all great, but will rarely deal with this stuff until #1 is taken care of. So my process starts with close mics.

After poking around and listening to the close mic various options to get a sense of what I’m working with, I’ll start with getting everything in phase. Solo the kick drum mics and get those in phase with each-other. If they don’t add up, I’ll start playing with HP filters at various Q’s to try and get things closer. You’d be surprised what you can get away with even when things are even 90 degrees out. Then, I’ll start introducing more spot mics (snare, toms, HH) and start getting things in focus with just phase flips. By the time you get to the overheads and rooms, you should have all the spot mics in phase with each-other so then you can get a better sense of how the overheads are going to play into the game.

author: cian riordan
content: If you have a mono sound on a mono track, it will sound mono. If you have mono sound on a stereo track, it will still sound mono. You can add delays, phasing, pitch shifting, etc to make it sound 'wide'... and yes, it will theoretically take up more space in the mix. As far as taking up more headroom, there's just too many variables to figure out there. But if you have the mono sound on a mono track, and the mono sound on a stereo track, with modern pan laws, they would both take up the same headroom.

author: Slow Hand
content:
So to answer your question, yes, a sound will technically take up more headroom when hard-panned (or spread), because the pan law makes it a little louder when panned to the extremes. However because this also makes the sound perceptually louder you’re likely to turn the sound down a little bit to compensate for the boost in volume, thus buying you back the headroom you’d have lost.

I may have missed a few things. Other DAWs use other pan laws, and admittedly I'm not up to date on the minutiae of it all. So don’t hesitate to amend, or correct me on this stuff, folks.

author: David Fuller
content: Some DAWs like Pro Tools can actually change pan law. PT can do -2.5dB, -3dB, -4.5dB, and -6dB. Mixes sound different with different pan laws - and I'll bounce some stuff real quick to demonstrate.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I agree mostly with this! I’ve been playing instruments for 20 years and have made a living from it. If you want to get good, it is aactually pretty easy and anyone can do it with the right mindset and patience(key word here). Firstly stop playing on and off, just play as often as you can preferably every day if not every other day.  Stop worrying about scales chords and theory, and just play. Learn as many songs as you can, like really learn them. Your ear will get better at picking up details, like groove and technique over time, so just learn the songs as good as you can and then move one to the next. Try and make it through a 1000 songs over the next few years. You don’t need to remember them, just get through them and move on. You will pretty quickly start recognising patterns in music and realise most music is made up of the same few combinations of chords notes and so on. At this point I would recognise learning some theory, so that you will be able to name those musical patterns be it cadences, notes, chords, extensions and so on.  Then depending on what with your playing. This next bit is super important. If you don’t care about playing in bands or performing for people then you can do this whole thing by your self. But if you want to play with real people on a stage or a basement then you need to spend time playing with people as much as you can. Learn some songs go to a jam session either at a local pub, church or what ever you have in your city. Having friends who play is also great as you might be able to get a chance to play with them regularly, maby even make a band. When learning a song, make sure you can play it all the way through with either a metronome or a drum track before moving on. Video taping also helps to be able to get an objective look/listen to your playing so you will know, what you need to be mindful of. 

Keith Jarrett the pianist learned one 1000 songs the first year for a restaurant piano gig before he was known or good.

author: ALXCPH
content:
This is of course all perfect scenario stuff and will be impossible to do perfectly so don’t be hard on yourself if it seems like too much.

So in short just play a fuck ton and learn a Fuck ton of songs ✌️

author: oaklandmatt
content: @sloth the reason is use clip gain is so you're not relying on the limiter or compressor to level out the sound. rather, you're using the limiter or compressor for the SOUND it creates. if you want that super compressed sound (or even that lightly compressed sound) of an actual compressor or limiter, you'll often get better results if the signal going into it is evened out a bit. this used to be solved mostly by great mic technique, where a singer would lean back on big notes and whatnot. but these days by using clip gain to even out the sound before it hits your dynamic processing, you can actually more fully lean into the SOUND of the compressor or limiter that comes after it.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
I love (trying) to explain this because it always makes me think of new things to try.

You can stereoize a sound using lots of techniques, the main three being pitch, delay, and phase. Often times your favorite plugins will do combos of these, so flipping the phase on one side will sometimes kill some of your wideness.

It's worth doing a google, but something like a flanger is simply duplicating the signal and micro delaying one of them at a variable rate. So the duplicated signal might oscillate between 2-20 milliseconds, which makes that crazy flanger sound. If you take that duplicated signal and run it through an aggressive filter (which will introduce some phase shift) and that's what a phaser is. 

You can play with multiple duplicate signals, flipping phase on one side and getting wild effects. You can play with pitch on the delayed signal and start getting an effect we call "chorus." But of course, each of these types of effects are just combinations of fundamental ways to manipulate audio. Many combos are possible!

Hooray sound design!

Also, I would love @Slow Hand to correct and expand, since I know he (and many others on here) are REAL sound design nerds.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Yeah. I suppose it would come down to the particulars of a given reverb, but I think your rationale is mostly correct. The verb may already be de-correlating the L/R channels (making them different from each other) in the optimal amount.

Something else to keep in mind is that different frequencies will likely have different amounts of phase rotation from the dry input signal, so flipping the polarity on one channel (left or right) might cause some frequencies to nullify and some to be accentuated. I wouldn't worry about trying to predict these relationships. It's all a mess by design. Use your ears and see what sounds good.

author: Will Melones
content:
Oh yeah, for sure. It’s easy to overdo it, and satisfying enough that sometimes you don’t know in the moment.

Ultimately you can be 100% in the right speaker or 100% in the left speaker, and pushing beyond that is tempting the gods. As far as I can conceive it, any process that attempts to widen a signal that’s already entirely decorrelated must have the potential to reintroduce some correlation. Thinking again of the ping pong delay, is there really anything wider than that?

I was doing a lot of M/S mix buss widening stuff a few years ago, and I realized that it could do some pretty weird shit to panned vocals and the like. While it feels like you can just ‘turn up the sides’, you’re really doing something unnatural to the center, too, and the relationship between channels. Like you’re choosing select bits of a sound to turn up, but only the bits of that sound that don’t have anything in common with the other speaker. This is a lot of rambling just to say that there’s clearly a point of diminishing returns, and maybe the solution is to pan something else less wide to create contrast.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Pretty much all the info above is great for general understanding. (And I do mean *great*)

To answer your other question, my personal approach usually leads me to making up 2-3db on 2buss processing. So before I instantiate and add any gain from inflators or limiters at the end of my master fader chain, I have 2-3db of headroom. 
Starting with kik snare bass around -6db, adding in vocals and everything else all balanced properly usually gets me to around -2. Which is more than enough for a mastering engineer but not enough to get myself into trouble tryna get to make it loud with my Ozone or whatever. 

That’s just my process currently. No doubt there’s different ways to get there, some likely much better, but this has been working well for my purposes.

author: LAPhill
content:
Are you looking for resources on writing/production, or mixing? Just like with the record side, there's so much noise from bedroom composers and people that have zero real-world experience. And as Ruairi is always saying, even the people with real success often can't teach what they know. Maybe I'm a bit cranky after an 8 hour delay at the airport yesterday, but Spitfire has gotten quite good at creating "tutorial" videos that are thinly veiled advertisements, and many of their libraries are the equivalent of one-knob plugins or CLA vocals. Selling paint-by-numbers solutions to naïve kids who want to get into scoring (They're far from the only ones guilty of this). But to focus on some of the channels I think are actually worth their salt:

8-Bit Music Theory: https://www.youtube.com/@8bitMusicTheory/videos
Can be a bit basic at times, but he talks a lot about structure which, IMO, is becoming a lost art in modern scoring.

Anne-Kathrin Dern: https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWJg1w7F3PKPbSpEF2YOejVjWAg-KcM3Z
Not the biggest name out there, but she has a no-bullshit way of explaining things about orchestration and theory that is clear and concise. As far as "teachers," I think she's a good one.

Alan Meyerson Waves Sessions: https://youtu.be/h9jZqn5lnw4
I hesitate to include this. I know for a fact that Alan swapped out a bunch of his go-to plugins to make everything a Waves product. I haven't watched this in awhile, but it's a good insight into how he sets up a big mix session and why he makes some of his decisions. author: David Fuller
content:
As a mixer the things I'd look for beyond the obvious (are their mixes good)...
- are they easy to work with? 
- are they open to revisions?
- if they're local, are they okay with attended mix sessions? (Generally past the first pass, fwiw)
- have they worked on a bunch of different styles and done good mixes in all of them?
- failing that, have they done a lot of records in the genre your record is in and done them all well? (Some genres have very specialized mixers, so this is a worthwhile consideration)

author: Will Melones
content:
Hmm I’ve always handled this with the subtlest amount of fader automation I can get away with. Just enough of a dip on the sustained note so the focus shifts to the incoming line, and the lyrics are intelligible, but without making the first line trail off (unless that’s the desired effect).

I think of those musicals where there’s a big chorus and everyone’s singing different counter lines on top of one another. It’s like a chaotic puzzle, but what you realize is that the lyrics to the counter lines are all lines you’ve heard earlier in the show. So your brain can fill them in without really listening, and the arranger’s job is to use a spotlight to continually move your focus to the most important melody at any given moment.

content: Check out Ethan Gruska’s album Slowmotionary—is the piano sound at all like that? If so I’d use that as a North Star. Or Phoebe Bridgers Punisher. Knowing Noire a bit I imagine it might be that real rolled off kinda vibe. When I’ve mixed stuff like that, I do a combo of aggressively attenuating the boominess, and using Spectre/Neutron exciter/Saturn to get as much life out of the midrange as I can before things start getting crunchy or harsh. Then you gotta also just remember that it was the sound they chose and you need to respect that. So it’s a balance.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
One approach to recalling board mixes a la Ben Baptie: If there’s a tweak, he pulls up the relevant stem (printed through the board) against the mix and flips its phase, essentially taking it out of the mix (or enough to make adjustments then recombine through ITB mix chain).

Might not work as well if there’s wow and flutter on your Otari, but could be worth experimenting with?

author: Adam Thein
content:
A few more that I use constantly:

Cmd + K for Key Mapping (great for auditioning a chain)

In adaptive grid mode:
Cmd + 1 for more subdivisions in grid
Cmd + 2 for fewer subdivisions in grid
Cmd + 3 for triplet grid

Hold Cmd to override grid for selections and moving clips
Shift + Opt + Cmd and click and drag within a clip to slip audio within clip region

Shift + Cmd + R to enter export screen

For arranging things quickly shift modifier will add or remove time and move all automation.  For example:

Shift + Cmd + D = Duplicate and add time
Shift + Cmd + X = Cut time
Shift + Cmd + V = Paste copied time

author: Adam Thein
content: Life savers - caution though that if you have something like Melodyne plugin and add or remove time the audio stored within the memory of the plugin will not be edited, so render anything like that to audio before editing time

author: Ross Fortune
content:
It made sense that time around as it was an 86 min live show of 30-40 tracks. RX took ~5mins, while PT was looking at +1hr. I haven’t braved the downsample and relink approach. 

If it were a complex session but you know the comps are final, and all fades have been checked etc, another solution might look like the following (though with all these steps it’d likely be faster in PT):

- batch rename audio tracks in PT to prepend with 2 digit numbering (01, 02, 03…), or 3 digit if +100 tracks
- consolidate all audio to bar 1 (previous step ensures useful sequential naming of the consolidated files, a big help later)
- export consolidated audio files to finder
- batch downsample in RX
- save copy of PT session at new sample rate, don’t include audio
- drop downsampled audio from RX into corresponding tracks in new session, *automation follows edit* OFF)

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Hey howdy hey. Stream of consciousness response here:

First of all- great question. Haven’t seen you around these parts yet so I don’t know your situation and can’t speak to your specifics. But, there are some overarching philosophical ideas worth considering. 

1) the answer to each of these questions is different for every person. None of us got into music because we’re risk averse and looking for stability, so dont think just cause you’re “going full time” or you start calling it a “career” that somehow that will be different. 

2) and this is universally true, you’ll never be younger or have fewer responsibilities than you do now.

3) don’t take the leap if you’re not willing to: be poor. Have roommates. Eat ramen. Breakup with girlfriends/boyfriends who expect more from you. Borrow money for your cellphone bill. Drive a shitty car. Etc etc. 

But also, if you don’t bet on yourself, no one else is going to either.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I think it’s less about being turned away from basic questions and just more about helping us help you. If I asked “what’s the best compressor”, I wouldn’t receive many truly helpful answers because chances are there’s a reason I’m asking why, a problem I want to solve with X piece of gear. Providing context helps the answers give context because as Adrian said, there is no silver bullet. Just a framework of reps that help inform the decision that fits for whatever context you’re in. Context is everything in music, otherwise we’d only have one drum sound for everything.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Turn off the click, press play, do some pushups. How does it feel? 

You didnt notice when you were playing probably cause it felt just fine. A click consistent to itself (despite not being consistent with another daw) is likely going to feel just fine. 

Kick being on and snare being ahead can feel great, kick being ahead and snare being on can feel great, kick & snr being on and hats being ahead can feel great… deep breath, go find the joy. Music is magic, DAWs are just tools. Dont let it steal the fun; this IS the fun part.

author: cian riordan
content: FWIW, the whole all-pass, frequency specific phase adjustment feature of the UTA eq was a pleasant surprise after the inclusion of the -40dB notch feature. 15 years ago, to my knowledge, there were no hardware EQs that were able to pull this off -- so UTA marketed it as a nice bell and whistle for the console. I've used this feature exactly zero times and only saw Eric make use of it for product demonstrations.

author: Zack Hames
content:
There’s no right or wrong in this regard.

If you’re landing the transitions really cleanly between the different levels of overdrive you’re golden. 

You’re getting suggestions from folks who probably got burned on records where it was done poorly or it would have been easier for them to separate and organize like @cian riordan said. He described the benefits of it perfectly. 

I’m impatient as *fuck* and prefer to cut as many things live and in 1 go as possible. I don’t like overly complex sessions, etc. it’s prob more of a shortcoming than benefit unfortunately.

author: spectrummasters
content:
Niiice , yes my structure is very similar . Added , For programmed music , I have a separate kick bus , and I tend to keep live (eg moog and or p bass ) to their own bus and 808s to their own buses also . Kick and bass might arrive to one shared bus pre 2hus if I want to clip them pre 2 bus . Tend not to clip much anymore tho  . All my drums go into  three parallels (a clean a distortion and a comp ) and those are what arrive to the drum bus . It was cians article that educated me to just how much “eq” I can do this way via distortion . This was a real level up for me . 
I do the same thing for my kick and basses and include a blown out high passed parallel to feather in at the end to tickle the tweeters once I’ve balanced the mix at the end .

author: spectrummasters
content:
In programmed music you can shape adsr in the sampler of course, but compression allows us to do this also

Embrace it man , get a feel for it and then you’ll have so much power to manipulate that pocket . Both of an instrument and its relationship to other instruments ….and then between buses etc .

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
Well, it all depends on what gear you have and/or want to use.

If you have a DI box, an outboard preamp you want to use, and an available line input on your interface yes.
If you have a DI box and an interface with built in mic preamps but no outboard preamp, do that. If you have an interface with an instrument input but no DI box and no outboard mic preamp do that.

Some outboard preamps even have a DI input on it that sounds pretty good, but without knowing your exact setup idk what to advise. Based on the above info though you should be able to make that choice.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here goes…
Million ways to skin this cat. I’ll give you food for thought.

1. At least double track. My personal goal, is to get the sound to be as awesome and huge and perfect with 1 pair of guitar tracks doubled, with 1 mic on an amp. That’s the ideal scenario for me. That said There are people that sum 4 mics down to 1 signal on a mixer and it sounds amazing.  

2. The more performances  you add of the same part, the more blurry it will sound.if you need different textures, consider recording a DI so it can be blended in with your amp in any manner of your choice, either reamping, distorting with a plugin, whatever. (Check phase)

3. I like when the left and right are *subtly* different, no drastically different. You hear “the left and right being different is what makes something wide”
This is true. But I loathe when it’s so different it feels lopsided.

How do we address this? 

-double track using the same guitar so the tuning and intonation is most similar 

-change the amp head but keep the same cabinet/speaker so the overall EQ is similar but my the gain structure is different

If you use 2 different guitars, consider the scale lengths. This will change subtle intonation things, for better or worse.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also….
Try tracking one take 
Track your double
Remove the initial track, and THEN double over your second take. I find this gets the rhythm and vibe much tighter when you double over a double

author: Zack Hames
content: Also, let your bass be the thing that lives below 150hz. Not that you need to hi pass at 150hz. But don’t let big huge wallowing low end eat up your mix.

18. Repeat steps 1-17 till satisfied

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Short answer; it’s program dependent. And everything depends on everything. 

Long answer:

I spent a long time hoping MEs would answer these questions for me, but honestly not a one of them knows wtf they’re doing. Certainly not enough to quantify things like “how much louder will I make your track.”

Best thing I did along the way was develop relationships with MEs. Usually one at a time, and worked through my questions in real time. Figured out what happened when masters come back and i felt amazing vs when they come back and I felt just ok. 

Over time I’ve developed a philosophy for myself, (and while that changes/evolves over time,) I’m now confident when I send a mix to master that what I’ll get back will be a more finished  version of my ideas. And “more finished” is not necessarily correlated to “how loud.”

author: Rollmottle
content:
Just taking the time to figure out the right changeover strategy and timing so that I could actually make the move once I basically had two fully functioning rigs stood up in parallel. My additional complicating factor is having a laptop that is a dupe of the studio rig, so keeping it all straight and everything in sync is a bit of a puzzle. 

I took the transition as the opportunity to phase out some mechanical drives so I had to get some new drives for the M4 instead of re-using the old Time Machine mechanical drive. The M4 mini only has Thunderbolt/USB C ports -- the M1 has USB A's and Thunderbolt/USB C's so I needed a TB hub to get my old USB hub to play on the M4. The move forced me to sort out my iLok strategy between my mastering rig and my production rig because it was quite messy (I ended up getting a 2nd iLok for the M4 to make things way easier between it and the laptop). It was just a lot of little stuff for me. If you're not changing machine form factors and it's mostly a software exercise, then it might be worth it.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Alright gang - i've got this Otari MX5050 up and running and I wanted to ask if anyone had recommendations for buying new 1/4" tape reels to record with in 2025/26.

Research I've done seems spotty, some people saying they've bought new tapes that were already shedding/sticky, etc. just wanted to see if anyone had current info or advice.


SIde question; apparently after some time, tape reels simply go bad and have to be baked more or less every time you want to use them. So for those who have been using tape for a long while or did back in the day, you can't just use any old reel after baking it for a project? or can you say, bake it, use it for the project (record 2 track mix to tape, etc) and then just store it and re-bake it and use it again for the next project? 

I didn't grow up with tape but I love the sound and find the whole process romantic, despite how much extra work calibrating tape machines and maintaining them and the unpredictable nature of tape.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
When successful music producers talk about "mentors," it's almost always working under someone. This usually starts out as an internship or assistant position of some sort. Some come through your network of music friends, some come from doing exceptional work and people further along in their career taking notice, and some come from applying to the various "looking for an assistant with xyz qualifications" posts you see here and on social media.

I made an album with a local band called the Matches up in Oakland. They started getting attention from record labels and big producers in LA. I moved to LA and met Eric Valentine who liked the album and met with the band. I asked if I could intern for him. He said he didn't have interns but I should stay in touch cause sometimes they hired extra help. I called him every two weeks for the next six months until an opportunity opened up. Then I assisted him for five years while making indie records on the side.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
My advice is to have in person interactions as much as possible. When it comes to making records at a super high level (intense, stressful, high standards, egos, deadlines, freakouts, etc), you need to build a level of trust that for me is impossible without spending time with a person.

It doesn't mean you can't build a career remotely, but it's harder. Not only is it harder to build trust, but the remote option is available to anyone with an internet connection. So you're competing with a much larger pool of people too.

Does that mean move to LA or London or Miami or wherever? Not necessarily. But finding a way to get in person with the kinds of people you want to work with is extremely important

author: Zack Hames
content:
here's my 2 cents;

I used to feel the same way - i wanted the snare and kick to be very "Centered" in my room mics and overheads. and i'd get these like, super forward, up front snare sounds in those mics. Then I'd pull up my snare mic. and it sounded...the same.  I found that if the snare sounds the same in the OH's and rooms as it does in the close mic, it ends up sounding smaller bc of phase or lack of variety.

if you're using 16 drum channels and 8 of them sound the same, what's the point?

The OH's and rooms for me with that many microphones, i am trying to get width or energy. so the differences between the left and right is what makes it sound big and immersive, and let's the snare mics be their own thing dead center. 

Now, if I am doing a 1-5 mic setup, I will concern myself more with all of that stuff and try to get the snare to sound really great and centered.

author: Zack Hames
content: it's like if anything the weird shitty thing I am hearing is gonna rip in the mix. I love "blowing peoples minds" when they are like "that snare is super ringy" when it is soloed, then the whole drum mix comes in and you would never call it ringy.

author: Zack Hames
content: ESPECIALLY dense guitar music.

author: Zack Hames
content: for my usual big mic setup, the cymbalas are so much louder in the OH's than the snare, it couldn't possibly matter.

author: oaklandmatt
content: The easiest thing is just different mic positioning. The classic is to stand a few feet back from the mic and record BVs that way. If you have multiple mics, just try a different mic for BVs. See if you like the contrast. It's a creative decision more than anything else. Close mic, stacked harmonies with the same mic as the lead vocal also sound nice. Just depends what you're after. Experiment and let your ears decide!

author: Slow Hand
content: One approach that hasn't been mentioned is using a different singer/singers for the backgrounds so that they contrast the lead vocalist. That can add a ton of character to a track and keep the timbre from being same-y.

author: Slow Hand
content: Or, if you don't have other singers handy, adopt a "character" when performing your backgrounds. Kendrick Lamar is great at this. If he's tracking a chorus (group of vocalists) responding to his lyrics they'll have a distinct affect to differentiate the different narrative personalities.

author: Slow Hand
content: Trey Spruance once described his process for multi-tracking a string section using one violinist (I'm paraphrasing): "After each string take I give the player a new prompt about their personality: "Now you're second violin and you're gunning for first-chair's spot, so you're gonna be trying a little too hard and playing just a hair too loud to get the conductor's notice. You've got something to prove." or "Now you're 6th chair and you're just happy to be here. Your vibrato is going to be a little lax." Etc, etc, etc.

author: Slow Hand
content: So I'd sum it up as: Unless you're seeking homogeneity in your backgrounds, start with the performer/performance aspect.

author: Slow Hand
content: @hendrick Am I recalling correctly, that you're relatively new to guitar playing?

author: Slow Hand
content: Generally speaking, steel string guitars are more common in pop music. They've got that jangly, biting, tone. Possibly because that tone can cut through a dense arrangement easier or be more aggressive. Nylon strings are associated more with classical performance or something like flamenco, but nylon strings can certainly find their way into pop music too. 2000s RnB/Hip Hop was all about that.

author: oaklandmatt
content: @hendrick these are awesome!

author: Slow Hand
content: FYI, They're playing a steel string in the Usher video, but it's still a nylon on the recording.

author: Slow Hand
content: The other big difference is the neck/fingerboard shapes. Steel string necks are typically akin to electric guitars. If you can play electric guitar you'll pick up a steel string easy, while a nylon guitar takes a little bit of adjustment because the fretboards are much wider and the string spacing is wide to match. It's nothing you can't get used to, but it can lead you to different playing styles on each.

author: Slow Hand
content: One question I would consider, though, is whether or not to bypass any master limiting for the live version of the track. If the mix is such that you're taking off a lot of transients on the master buss, it may sound better to ease off the limiter or bypass it entirely so that the live sound engineer will have plenty of headroom to work with and isn't trying to mix around a track that's massively limited. Having that extra headroom and transient energy could be a benefit, thought you'll have to use your ears to make that judgement, and definitely talk to the artist.

author: Slow Hand
content: It could be that the limiter is what's gluing the entire mix together and without it the track loses a certain feel. In such a case, you probably would not want to do that, if the limiter is holding it together.

author: Rollmottle
content: When I've done it, I've left the limiter on so that everything coming out of the Live set is a known quantity and level can be dealt with on the analog side. Done for level and practical reasons, not tonal.

author: Slow Hand
content: So whatever you and the artist decide, do your best to make the live tracks you print have a consistent level. You can't control the mixes they get from others, so you'll need to talk to the artist and see what they're already using.

author: Rollmottle
content: In my case, it's been a club setting and the tracks need to be jamming so I applied a bunch of processing across the 2-bus to achieve a consistent "mastering" level...especially when the source is a mix of mastered tracks and non-mastered tracks, you gotta level match what's going into the 2-bus and then make sure everything coming out is generally at the same level without crushing everything.

author: Rollmottle
content: That certainly makes sense!

author: Zack Hames
content:
So I just sent masters to a label - digital and vinyl. 

How involved have you been in test presses and selecting which one gets pressed? Has the band ever had opinions? Are you trying to find the one that is most faithful to the original files sent?

author: Rollmottle
content: The point of the test pressing isn't to pick one, it's more of a sanity check on the vinyl master.  I would always recommend an acetate to avoid the pain in the ass of discovering a problem with your master at test pressing. The acetate precedes the sign off on the master and allows you to hear what your music MIGHT sound like on a record. It is definitely lesser quality than a test pressing and a full vinyl run, but the $80 or $100 it costs will be money well spent to avoid a wasted cycle and cost of a bunk test-pressing.

author: Eric Martin
content: also, removing any additional distortion/clipping on the master will help translate better, as the cutting will impart a character to it, and the cutting engineer will do EQ before it hits the heads to control the level going onto the acetate.

author: Rollmottle
content: I've been running a primarily vinyl label since 2000 or so and vinyl's an absolute fucking pain in the ass. Something ALWAYS goes wrong. (I stopped pressing a few years ago...can't deal anymore...it's gotten too expensive to do right and the wait times are insane for little guys like me)...all that said, I love vinyl lol, but not pressing it.

author: Slow Hand
content: Could you post a link to it? I'm not familiar with FX pedals. Is that a company? Or are you simply referring to *any* effects pedal?

author: Slow Hand
content: Gotcha. Generally speaking, effect pedals don't interface directly with a computer or plugins (although some can). Usually they can only be recorded as audio by plugging them into your audio interface and recording the audio as you perform it. I see that this one has a *MIDI In/Out*. That means it can probably receive *tempo* information (so that it synchronizes with other programs) and maybe some *program changes* that can tell it when to change presets.

author: Slow Hand
content: But it sounds like you're interested in using the pedal as outboard processing? Meaning you want to take a sound that's already in your computer, send it to the pedal and then re-record it back into the computer. Is that correct?

author: Eric Martin
content: I use pedals on productions and mixes all the time, my Appgee Ensemble has a DI IN AND OUT on the front of the box so it’s real easy

author: peterlabberton
content: This thing will do what ya need

author: peterlabberton
content: You'd need something to act as a reamp... someone on here will be able to explain this better in technical terms, but basically you need to get the level down to instrument level, where the pedal lives, and then a DI/mic pre to get it back in. This is kind of an all-in-one solution.

author: peterlabberton
content: https://www.radialeng.com/product/prormp This would be cheaper if you already have a DI

author: peterlabberton
content: They have a higher end model as well which has a trim on the output (so you can adjust level) and a basic filter going to the pedals, but this will definitely do the trick. Probably cheaper options than Radial but they make good shit that will last.

author: peterlabberton
content: Exactly—you'd go from a line output on your interface, into the XLR on the reamp box, out of the 1/4", into your pedal(s), and then from there into your DI/interface. Pedals are super fun for this stuff!

author: peterlabberton
content: Exactly. Say you’re using line out 1-2 for monitoring, you could use line out 3 to feed the reamp/pedal(s), and then just whatever input you want/whatever your DI is on. If you’re in Pro Tools you can setup a hardware insert, though you’d have to use the same ins and outs (i.e. output 3, input 3).

author: Slow Hand
content: Unless you're doing scientific testing, I would think that there is very little reason to ever need 32 bits of audio information when making music. 24 bits of dynamic range is already huuuge.

author: Slow Hand
content: I think there's a case to be made for DSP processing in your plugins at 24bit vs 16bit, in order to avoid artifacts. But I think to go higher would be diminishing returns.

author: Slow Hand
content: Happy to help. I suspect someone else may eventually chime in with something that I've overlooked, so check back in later.

So it's hard to know the right answer, but I rarely do this, even when I was starting out. Just a bad precedent.

author: Eric Martin
content: the more you charge, the more people will value you too, have you listened to the “Attack and Release Show” that podcast talks about rates a lot and they firmly believe in upping your rate sooner than later.

author: peterlabberton
content: You can also approach it, as I did for quite a while, from a monthly cost angle. If you want to work 20 days a month, maybe build in a healthy buffer so that if you only book 10, you’ll still make ends meet. Make a day rate from there, and an hourly rate from that. I’ve played this out several times over the years, and it usually comes out pretty close to where most working engineers settle in whichever city I was in at the time.

author: Zack Hames
content:
How can I get better low end from my kick drum? 

My usual setup is a D112 right outside the hole pointing at the batter, then either a tube condenser or rn a Warm Audio 47 fet, a few feet away pointing at the kick, low passed at 50-100hz and delayed maybe 150-300ms to get the low end nice and full and make some sort of phasing miracle happen. 

I am so close to getting the sound I want, it just sounds a little less thick and a little less rock solid than what I am chasing. What am I missing? What can I try?

author: David Fuller
content: Also I really never have a kick out that far off

author: Zack Hames
content: This is my version of a sub kick. Basically the idea is to have the low end happen a little later than the attack, intentionally. I’ve used sub kicks and they’re just okay for me, but maybe I don’t know the best way with them. I’ve played with the distance quite a bit, sometimes it’s a couple feet from the center, sometimes it’s exactly even with the dynamic mic.

author: Zack Hames
content: These are good suggestions, especially about the drummer’s playing.

author: peterlabberton
content: @Zack Hames I’d also add to the above to not be afraid to just go for it with an eq. Bus all the kick tracks together, and use a high pass with a high q and boost until it hits right. Depending on the drum/recording and how you want it to hit in the mix, I often find a good spot between about 60 and 80 hz that has good weight and punch, and just boost by adjusting the q to taste.

author: peterlabberton
content: Also... I think I’d try your FET closer to the head, and then if you want to try delaying it a touch, trying it from there, OR throwing another mic up a few feet away for that option

author: Zack Hames
content: Great advice. I know I’ll need some mixing to get there I’ll try the FET closer to maybe make it “punchier” low end. Thanks man!

author: Slow Hand
content: If tracking is already complete and you want more subby frequencies on a kick, you could try gating a low-tuned sinewave off of the kick. That should give you a lot of control over how the low-end envelope breathes. Has anyone had good results with that?

author: peterlabberton
content: I haven’t tried that in years—maybe I could get it to work better now, but I couldn’t consistently make that work. I know I mixed a few songs that use this, though! I’ve become more and more into using eq as I described above to manufacture or tune a weighty kick sound instead of the gated sine move. In addition to/instead of the above, I sometimes duplicate the kick track, and low pass, make the q resonant, and tune the frequency so it works well in the song. Then, blend back into the drums, and play with phase until it all adds up nice.

author: Eric Martin
content: you can also do the Steve Albini trick where you send back to the same channel and get that to resonate off the same source

author: Eric Martin
content: totally, number one thing that makes the low end speak IMO

author: peterlabberton
content: I’m sure you’ve read this or could find it with a quick google search, but starting with the first reflection points would be my first step. Side walls next to the listening position and ceiling above. Then probably behind the listening position and perhaps behind the speakers. If you have anything to use as a bass trap, I’d recommend using something like fuzzmeasure to shoot the room and experiment with placing that stuff in different places. You’ll be able to see peaks and valleys moving around in the low end, assuming what you’re using is actually effective at sucking up bass. There are people with much more knowledge than me, but that’s where I’d start!

author: Rollmottle
content: in most cases, putting your speakers up against the front wall will be the way forward

author: Rollmottle
content: the concept is to couple your speakers to the front wall to remove or minimize SBIR and to leverage the room gain you get by being up against the boundary and then treat that energy at the rear wall. you will see most folks recommend this approach in small room contexts. i forget what exactly is considered an acoustically small room but most all residential rooms fall into this bucket.

author: peterlabberton
content: I found this to be true in my current studio. There was a null somewhere around 80hz with my speakers a little further out, and moving them closer to the wall lowered that null in frequency significantly. Not sure if this is what the science says, but that seemed to be my experience. Got it much less in a critical zone, then threw some bass traps on either side of the speakers and lessened it even more.

author: David Fuller
content: If you have the space for it and your monitors can be mounted as such, soffits are a great idea

author: David Fuller
content: It removes the influence of sbir entirely and actually improves bass response by making effectively an infinite baffle

author: cian riordan
content: As in, printing on vinyl just as an effect or they want to press their album to vinyl?

author: cian riordan
content:
I would tell them there's a few things to consider when pressing vinyl:
1) Mastering is especially important as it’s the real bridge between the music and the mechanical production of the record. I had the great pleasure of mastering a few records for vinyl with Doug Sax (give him a google) and there’s a lot more to the process than modern mastering for digital services. They will actually cut the acetate disc which will be what manufacturers use to make the metal stamper that actually molds the records. A lot of thought goes into this process such as the width of the grooves to accommodate bass frequencies, etc. If you want a good sounding record, there’s no way around working with a seasoned professional.

2) Side lengths are important, as is track order. The more music you put on a side of vinyl, the less fidelity it will have as a whole. There will be sacrifices in the manufacturing to accommodate all of the music, so it’s best to keep your side lengths under 20 mins. Closer to 15 mins per side is ideal sonically, but sometimes that means doing double records and that just gets expensive. Also the order in which the tracks play on each side plays a part. The songs at the beginning of the side have more bandwidth and less distortion… it basically diminishes the closer you get to the center. Whatever the last track on the side is will just sound worse. It’s a flaw in the medium… so think about that.

author: oaklandmatt
content: it's possible but challenging. there are definitely scales besides major and minor that work in pop songs ("pop" meaning anything that gets popular). but if you don't have good experience and/or a decent grasp of music theory, it's tough to not make it sound weird. it's a bit like doing tempo changes or odd time signatures: mostly it sounds crazy to a mainstream music audience, but if done just right, it can be unique and amazing.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. There are lots of theoretical explanations for different scales/modes that would work, but you're probably better off just using your ear. If it sounds good, it is good. Go for it!

author: peterlabberton
content: Nerding out on some drummer shit might really come in handy—go listen to some of The Meters and listen to Zigaboo’s feel. That was a big thing for me learning sort of “in between” feels that can’t really be defined on a grid. Getting the nuances of different degrees of swing on different subdivisions can get kind of mind-bending until you have an intuitive feel for it.

author: Slow Hand
content: That's such a neat topic. Lately I've been putting a huge emphasis on groove and feel, as someone who programs drums (but doesn't play). I'm mostly nudging everything by hand and trying not to resort to anything like a DAW's swing. Do you have any resources you'd recommend for exploring the concept of timing/swing on groove?

author: peterlabberton
content: The internet can be pretty neat sometimes. I was really into New Orleans drumming in high school, which I feel really goes deep on these nuances of swung/straight—I had an instructional DVD from this very drummer talking about this very exercise, which was super helpful at the time: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PQaU_tCbjg

author: peterlabberton
content: In terms of translating this to programming... I don't do a *ton* of programming, since I'd always rather just play something 🙂 But just manipulating the placement of the upbeats is basically what he's doing here. You keep the eighth note straight, and move every *other* eighth note that's not on a beat by varying amounts... as he says, you're just trying to find the balance of where it feels good/isn't hokey.

author: peterlabberton
content: In the video I had in high school, he spends more time on the first exercise, which I feel like he kind of glosses over here. Just setting a metronome and playing eighths, and smoothly going from purely straight to super, over the top swung, and then smoothly transitioning back to perfectly straight is a good one to practice.

author: Slow Hand
content: Wow. Thank you. Great recommendation and an interesting concept to think about. Drummers are so neat when they have that total control.

author: Slow Hand
content: On a side note, since you mentioned New Orleans drumming, I'm obligated to mention the show *Treme* that ran on HBO around 2010. That's probably the best show about music I've ever seen. It's such a celebration of the music life and it oozes with love for the art form (not to mention food and everything else it touches on). *Strong* recommendation.

author: peterlabberton
content: Yeah! I’ve seen the first one or two episodes but fell off for some reason. I looove The Wire and I’m sure Treme is excellent, too. Will revisit!

author: Zack Hames
content:
Also beyond “fixing” the best thing i ever learned for drum mixing was drum bus compression, and using saturation on close mics.

My usual chain is this:
All kick and snare mics get some sort of eq if needed. Then I’ll put fab filter Saturn 2 and saturate the high end at around 700hz.

The I’ll bus all the drums to an aux. then I’ll usually do this:
Tape saturation (waves J37)
Parallel drum compression with a mix knob (fast release, slow attack) I use the kush audio AR-1, I used to use the waves abbey road mastering plugin. 

Sometimes I’ll use wavesfactory Spectre to boost highs and lows after all that. Maybe soundtoys Sie-Q to boost midrange.

author: cian riordan
content:
Template:
I’ve attached a slimmed down version of my mix template with all of the drum bussing. This has evolved over many years and has taken many forms, but it’s really just a good starting point for me and speeds up my workflow quite a bit. I’ve got three main busses that feed into a master drum buss. ‘DRUM SUB’ is my uncompressed (or lightly compressed) buss. ‘DRUM PAR’ is my heavily compressed buss, and ‘DRUM DIST’ is my parallel distortion buss. I don’t necessarily always use these, but having them ready to go makes it easier to quickly audition different ideas. Sometimes I’ll duplicate one or two of them to get another flavor involved. Again, everything to taste. 

Also in the template are some very basic aux’s I find myself using often. There are two parallel SansAmp busses. I have two because often times if I use one on the kick drum, it rarely works for the snare drum, so I have a second one ready to go. There’s also a ‘SNARE SLAP’ and ‘SNARE GATE VERB’ that rarely get used but if I need to inject a little mojo, they’re a good starting point.

The ‘D SUB TRIM’ is just a master fader controlling everything going into the bussing, so if I get a little overzealous with level, I can manage the gain staging quickly without having volume automation grouped. These three (sometimes more) busses then feed into the final ‘DRUM MSTR’ , where I’ll do final overall EQ tweaks and level adjustments.

author: cian riordan
content: https://www.dropbox.com/s/10kkcrmbp2muipi/CR%20DRUM%20TEMP.ptx?dl=0

author: cian riordan
content:
I'll gate everything with the Pro-G. Usually as tight as I can while sometimes automating threshhold to make sure ghostnotes don't get lost. I'll peel back the ratio once I have everything triggering properly to let some bleed in to taste. Sometimes I'll only gate 2-3 dB to just get something to pop. Sometimes its in a vaccum.
I will very rarely compress individual drum mics. And I pray that the recording engineer didn’t either. I like most of my compression to come from the busses. It sounds more natural to my ear and allows you to get away with a more compressed, exciting sound than just whacking the close mics. I’ll find at the beginning my drum mixes will be very ‘pokey’ — I want each drum to sound explosive and over the top. That way when i start compressing them, they maintain their transient quality when they start getting dynamically reduced.

I’m always cutting tons of 250-350 out of the kick drums and trying to manufacture any attack with saturation instead of EQ. Having a SansAmp or a Saturn plugin adding high end always sounds more natural to me than just additive EQ. I’m always very wary of the 2-5khz region, and find even-order harmonics are the best bet to fill in the blanks there.

I tend to like my snare drums warm, so often low-shelving down the super low end and keeping the 150-300 ‘boosh’ intact. I try to avoid using HPF on drum mics because at this point, things should be relatively in phase, so if I put a filter on, it’s going to throw the whole kaboodle off whack. Shelves are your friend here. And same as with the kick drums re: adding high end — I’m wary off adding the snap in the 2-5khz range, I’ll try and have the body of the snare drum really singing so I only have to add a little bit of top end, often above 5khz just for some air.

author: cian riordan
content:
If I get through the kick and snare and find things starting to sound too ‘scooped’, I’ll try and fill in some blanks with parallel sansamp or the distortion buss. I like the distortion buss technique because if offers a consistency across all the tracks and you dont just have a distorted snare drum but pristine clean toms. Often its a Decapitator with a low shelf going into it killing some low end. I’ll solo this buss, get it to sound crunchy but not messy, then un-solo, bring the fader to neg-infinity, and blend it into taste. You’d be surprised how much excitement you get without totally fucking up the aesthetic of the drums.

As for samples? Sure! I’ve you’ve gone all-balls on these tracks and you’re still lacking what you think you need, then no shame in supplementing with samples. ‘Supplement’ being the key word here. I use the Massey DRT to extract MIDI from the kick & snare mics and then use Battery to trigger my samples. I have a few samples that just solve various problems for me. Sometimes just giving me the low end sub, or a 100 cycle knock. They can be helpful to punch your way through phasing issues and really get the meat and potatoes of the rhythm track holding its own. I will never ‘replace’ with a sample… there’s always something useful in the recorded track if you try hard enough.

content:
I have a bit of a weird technical question I can’t wrap my head around. That I’ve never really thought about before. (might be over thinking it). I’m gonna completely simplify and exaggerate. When we talk about making room in a mix, usually we usually talk about giving each sound it’s own space in the mix. I understand this from a frequency point of view. But when talking about mono vs wide sounds I’m kinda lost. 

If let’s say i have 2 sounds, one is mono and one is wide.  Would that leave one with more headroom compared to having the same 2 sounds both in mono? 

Or would the wide sound take up more head room, because to make a sound wide, it needs to be different on both sides. But doesn’t that mean that you would have double the amount of signal as you would need two different versions of the same sound playing at once to achieve wideness? 

Fx a mono guitar and a mono vocal both centre vs a completely anti phase guitar and mono vocal. I know the latter will make each sound more intelligible but wouldn’t you at the same time provide more information resulting in less headroom?

author: cian riordan
content: To play devils advocate, there's benefits to using gates instead of stripping audio. If you automate the threshold on the gate, then you have the benefit of manipulating the attack, release, and ratio of the gate while mixing. Sometimes i'll find when getting deep into the mix that opening the gates a little bit starts to make things sound a little bit more natural, while keeping the general effect of the gate.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Power question:

I just had a power strip completely die - and I think melt slightly! All the gear was totally protected (pretty nice power strip, but old at this point).  It had my Computer, my PMC twotwo8's, a synth, some other odds and ends plugged into it.

So, what are some best practices when it comes to power/electrical and recording/music gear? Does it really matter if things are on separate outlets if they all go to the same breaker? and if they are on separate breakers and then interconnecting later on, isn't there potential for ground loops / noise?

This is the first time I've had one completely fry - I've had things shut off but nothing like this.

author: David Fuller
content: That power strip probably had an internal short. Admittedly, I'm a little leery of running that much stuff off one circuit, especially stuff that draws lots of current on the same strip like the monitors and the computer.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Interesting, that must be it. 

Right, makes sense about not running them all together. Maybe I can put them on separate power strips at least, spread things out a bit.

author: Slow Hand
content: If I understand your question correctly, there is no difference between what you've described. Compression and expansion are simply turning the volume up or down. Dynamic EQ is no different aside from the fact that it's limited to a specific frequency.

author: Zack Hames
content: Compression is knocking level down at a certain threshold. Dynamic EQ can be used to compress or expand very specific EQ ranges at a certain threshold. It's like super focused multiband compression with the ability to expand or compress.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i actually don't know what this means. maybe someone on here can come explain. "gain movement" is "more transparent than compression" doesn't make sense to me. seems like the same thing.

other than that dynamic eq and multiband compression are essentially the same. there are multiband compressors that will split the signal into multiple bands by default, so you're gonna get some phase shift between the bands, even if you're not compressing. but some plugins you can disengage the bands so depending on the plug-in architecture, you'd presumably not be getting the phase shift if you're turning off the band splitting

author: Slow Hand
content:
@Maxim I think I understand your question a little better now. I believe you're thinking of compression as both A) reducing the volume and B) applying make-up gain. To achieve this with a dynamic EQ you have to set the amount of gain reduction but then you *also* need to boost the volume of that EQ band (like it was makeup gain, which it is).

Did I understand correctly?

author: Zack Hames
content:
Just a place to start - learn and practice all of the scale modes (Ionian, mixolydian, aeolian etc) and basic chords. (Major, minor, augmented, diminished, etc) 

Frankly you can start with just basic 3 note chord and expand to bigger chords and inversions. I am by no means an expert but I am a long time guitarist with 0 theory that learned theory via piano playing so hopefully this might give you a very basic direction rather than something overly technical.

author: Zack Hames
content: The other obvious place to start to get chops is to learn songs. Analyze them to understand the theory.

author: Slow Hand
content: One thing I'll say right now is that it's important to have a good fingering technique, so that you can move around quickly and fluidly. It's going to be the foundation of your technique and I wouldn't skimp on this step. I would seek videos of people who will explain strategies for fingering major scales in each key. It's a little tiring, but repeating these fingerings until you're very comfortable with them is a necessary step to building your facility.

author: cian riordan
content: Everything should be identical if the gain-staging is all setup properly. Obviously, it's nice to have access to individual items (cutting EQ on an instrument b/c its clashing w/ vocals, etc) but there's beneficial aspects to this workflow as well (limiting your options, DSP use-age, etc).

author: David Fuller
content: because they aren't balanced circuits

author: David Fuller
content: tl;dr: cables themselves can't be balanced, they're just wire - what makes a circuit "balanced" has to do with having two sources with equal impedance feeding a load with a differential amplifier on the other end.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You would get 0 benefit using a TRS cable for guitar because it is an unbalanced signal. It would cost more money and time for 0 benefit. Also with certain connections it may NOT work. 

You probably know this, but active monitors just use balanced cabling with TRS or XLR connectors. Passive use proper speaker cables which are unshielded and TS.

Speaker cables don't have any shielding because they are expecting to see a super hot signal.  So this would result in unwanted noise in your guitar signal / active monitor signal because line level is much lower than speaker level.

So in all cases it's pretty much best to use the correct cable for the correct job. You'll save money and your equipment's longevity and reliability.

author: David Fuller
content: This is what a basic differential amp looks like. I've labeled it so it's more obvious what everything is. The feedback loop isn't necessary, but is very common because it helps further linearize the circuit (and also in the case of op amps limit their gain, which for something like a common TL071/TL072/TL074 is about 120dB - or a factor of 1,000,000).

Context: I have been producing music in sincerity for maybe 3 years now, been a hobby since like 16. I’ve started to engineer out of necessity for my individual artistry, but one thing led to the next and I gained a fair bit of skill at it (or so I’ve been told, I’m still pretty insecure, honestly even being around all the really knowledge people on here makes my panic disorder go 📈). I’ve gotten an internship at a studio as a runner and a session assistant down here (it’s not paid but it’s not exactly unpaid), and I truly have learned a lot (I learn something new on the daily I swear), but I’ve yet to have any true guidance from an established figure yet (which very well may never happen), which I know isn’t necessary, but it absolutely makes me question my own abilities/career decisions despite what happens with my freelance work and I’m curious to know if this is like normal/how other people cope. 

Like, I’ve gotten a somewhat okay share of people who pay for my work as an engineer/producer/writer, but the “do you really know what you’re doing” doubt doesn’t fade easily—even when I’ve been paid by people on like label level budgets, I’m never really registering that success. I’ve had cool moments and landed spotify placements as a mixer for artists, and there’s this part of me that’s still somewhat ashamed that I do a lot more work for free than I care to admit. 

Maybe it’s the comments on the old episodes that has me spooked (Jon on #61 re: “not everyone can be a mixer”), but is this like just me or do even some of the really wicked smart people here still feel that—and if so, how do you guys handle the it?

author: Adam Thein
content: I definitely experienced this on my M1 Macbook - some explanation I saw seemed to make sense to me where the power saving/efficiency settings adjust the clock speed of the cpu cores to meet the demand/load.  I think similar features are implemented in Intel systems depending on how you have your power settings set in the BIOS and OS (at least in Windows).  So counterintuitively if you aren't pushing your cores to the limit they won't be operating as effectively.  When I'm working on the Mac I keep the buffer as low as possible and then tick it up during the mix process, and on Windows my machine is usually really stable at 1024 from start to finish in a mix so I just leave it there, but I've also disabled any sort of power saving stuff on my PC in the BIOS so the clock speeds should be relatively stable.  Again, I'm not sure if this is actually the cause or not but just what I've seen posted about online anecdotally!

author: David Fuller
content: oh the EQ design is *totally* different between the two. Constant Q (E) vs proportional Q (G) on the mid bands, shelf/bell switches for HF and LF (E) vs x3 and/3 switches for the mid band frequency controls (G)... plus the filters are never actually disengaged on the E, at least on the original brown knob version.

Something i've been noticing a lot lately is, when playing with width effects, i keep preferring, sticking to only one type of widening at a time, instead of combining. author: ehutton21

author: Zack Hames
