author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Ok Boyz and Girlz, buckle up. I’m trying some formatting stuff for clarity that may or may not work. I’m not sure this is the best place for this post but @Slow Hand  can advise and move or I can repost

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
__**Sample rates in modern record making**__

**What matters
What does not matter
And how to choose what to use**

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: **Tiny TLDR** - Which sample rate you use is not a deal breaker, or even close. You can make a great sounding record at any sample rate. There are edge cases where it can make a meaningful difference but in modern Pop, Rock and Hip Hop production it’s not *that* important

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Disclaimer - I’m going to play a little fast and loose with scientific terms here in an effort to make this useful for everyone. Fuller can clean up my mess if he wants 🙂

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: __**What matters? (Even a little bit)**__

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **Higher sample rates reduce aliasing.** There is effectively no difference between 44.1 and 48k here but a meaningful difference at 96k and above. Aliasing is caused by non linear processes like distortion, and dynamics processing (compressor or limiter). Lots online about what it is and why it happens but you can sum it up by saying it’s an inharmonic, digital sounding hash that can feel bright but in a kind of ugly way (but remember sometimes ugly is good)
- **Higher sample rates reduce the impact of Anti Imaging and Anti Aliasing filters in AD to DA converters.** Filtering is necessary for accurate capture and replay of analog signals, and it in the early days of digital it used to be a real challenge. Now it’s basically a solved problem, but if you are doing acoustic music, with delicate transient information there is still a small but real advantage to higher rates
- **Higher sample rates reduce overshoot and inter sample peaks on limiters.** This really only matters if you are sending your loud mixes directly to release, otherwise your mastering girl or guy should handle that

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: __**What does not matter? (Even though people will say it does)**__

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- **More samples (slices) per second equals a better representation of the analog waveform.** Within half the band of the sample rate (say up to 22.05k for 44.1k) this is demonstrably not true. I know that is confounding, but digital and information theory is basically miraculous
- **We can hear/feel/sense sounds above 20k.** We truly really cannot and if you experiment with significant energy above 20k you’ll actually see problems creep in for electronics and speakers etc. Information above 20k is not our friend (space for harmonic information to live without aliasing back excepted)
- **Working at multiples of 44.1k is better because the sample rate conversion will work better.** This used to be a little bit true a long time ago but hasn’t been for a long time. Use the SRC in iZotope RX on it’s stock preset to 44.1 and you are in pretty good shape
- **Digital EQs work better at higher sample rates because of cramping.** Cramping was an esoteric problem with older digital EQs that looked bad on analyzers but never actually sounded very bad. It’s a solved problem nowadays with most EQs.
- **Video and film is at 48k so we must start there.** Yes film and TV still work at 48k (although YouTube specs 44.1 now) but I have sent a million tracks for sync at 44.1 and it gets dropped in with SRC and away we go

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: __**TLDR**__ - So what to do practically in the real world? If I had a super fast and stable computer I would record, produce and mix at 96k. It’s subtly better in every way and you can introduce any of the “desirable” problems from lower sample rates at will. BUT BUT BUT….if there was even the tinniest chance that the rig would hiccup, or my drives would not access fast enough, or that I would have a glitch in a real session then I would absolutely start at 48k.

author: cian riordan
content:
This is a very broad question with many different answers, but I think the easiest way to sum up the concept of ‘gain staging’ is simply figuring out what level every ‘device’ is expecting and/or which level is ideal to get the results you want. These ‘devices’ can be a plugin, a piece of hardware, an A/D/A converter, an auxiliary bus, a mix bus, etc.

In analog world… there might be fathomable difference when a compressor or amplifier receives -10dBVU vs +10 dBVU. Accounting for these differences would be considered gain staging — and you’d be looking for what gets the ideal sound out of your box.

In digital world… some plugins may react similarly and others may not care if you’re sending -6dBFS or -0.01dBFS. It’s usually case by case as there are myriad plugins. You also need to consider what level the plugin is sending signal out — as this will affect how the next plugin processes the audio, or how much headroom it has to work with. Let’s say I’m sending signal out of a compressor plugin into an EQ plugin — and lets say I’m using the compressor to beef up mean volume of the signal and then I want to EQ some more low end into the signal after the fact. Well, I’m going to be adding gain in the compressor and then the level going into the EQ will be hotter than originally intended. Id want to trim down the output of the compressor (or the input of the EQ) so you have headroom to be able to boost those frequencies without clipping the output of the EQ. In a 32-bit floating mixer like Pro Tools, these issues become less audible as the mixer has higher headroom than its indicating, but you never actually know — and it’s best to just stick to the parameters that you have control over. If you were to do this same function with an analog compressor and EQ, there would be very noticeable distortion if you didn’t stage the gain properly.

author: cian riordan
content:
Sometimes gain staging is just managing the signals going to an auxiliary bus or a master fader. If you’ve got everything summing into - say - an aux bus in pro tools, and that aux bus is clipping, then that will be audible distortion going into the next gain stage. It may sound good, it probably doesn’t — so its something to account for earlier down the chain. If you’re going into a master fader in pro tools, and your signal is over 0dBFS, you can simply turn down the master fader, and it is actually turning down all the signals going to it, not just the output. This is useful because you can then throttle the input to your first plugin in the chain — say a limiter or maximizer. It’d be a shame to have a fancy clipper on your master bus, only to be clipping the signal in the chain before even getting to it.

It’s a bit of a scattershot answer to a scattershot question, but the reality is that everything affects everything in audio. And having your head wrapped around signals levels going in and out of things will help you make faster decisions and help you troubleshoot quickly when things aren’t sounding quite right.

author: ehutton21
content: Just going to briefly latch onto this point because everyone else was absolutely brilliant here and I see one spot to touch on, especially because it’ll be from the perspective of someone who’s probably working to hone this too, much like yourself.

author: ehutton21
content:
I wrote in my notes from the Bainz episode that the way each guest/mixer talks about gainstaging the various tracks of a mix, it definitely is the mixer’s version of a “business mission statement,” which @Slow Hand alludes to with the idea of talking about how one choice ripples to inform all of our other decisions. Gainstaging sets the record up to show off its best qualities—and are those qualities in the low end of a booming bass synth and the natural silky quality of the vocalist, or maybe you want the mid range to feel really detailed yet cohesive and warm. 

Understanding this, for me, made the finishing process that Jon talks about make sense. Level setting inherently overlaps with the kind of decision making process of EQing, which is something you can probably understand best from this clip of Bainz talking about how he can get a vocal to be so upfront in his mixes because he’s surgical in what he keeps in there. The way I understood it, he’s cleaned up the vocal a ton, set the levels of his tracks by what feels important to bring to the forefront for the listener, and then he uses those levels to inform his EQ moves throughout.

https://www.instagram.com/tv/CkSeHgrosyx/?igshid=YmMyMTA2M2Y=

author: ehutton21
content:
What Jon talks about doing with headroom, for me, didn’t make sense until I heard what Bainz said in different incarnations on different occasions. 

By turning everything down 6 DBs midway through or near the end of the mix process, and then slowly pushing levels up to set your “balance” and then taking an EQ and using it very deliberately, you get a real gut check on “have I been deliberate with what I’m emphasizing for the listener.”

author: ALXCPH
content:
To give and actual real life example.
I’ve begun working with a lot of artist I personally look up to and usually know what they want when coming into a session(but I use the same method for pretty much anyone). What I usually do before a session is make sure I have a bunch of finished beats(my own and from friend producers) that are in their general vibe. 

Then once they come in, ill ask them if they wanna cook something up together or just listen to some beats and get going. 

I usually have more fun cooking from scratch with them if they are into it,
But both are cool. And what ever gets the job done is the right answer.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Following last night's #👩🍳mixing-talk chat re good online sources of nuts & bolts audio info, I made the following list for my bud.

I want to make it robust so it can be a resource to provide whenever these question comes up, so come on gang, poke holes in it.

I've included an orchestral/scoring section, and having done a little work in that world I personally found these resources helpful, but maybe @LAPhill could chime in? Props to @Adam Thein for the general section.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
**General**

Interview style material can be great, and sources like Mix With The Masters where you can watch legitimate professionals working while they explain why they do what they do. Of course, you first need to understand the tools in order to understand why people use them in certain ways in specific situations, so building your knowledge of the fundamentals is important.

In general beware of anything with hyped titles like “30 MIXING HACKS I WISH I KNEW”. The internet is awash with misinformation, so it’s important to assess who the information is coming from, and what their agenda may be (whether that’s building subscribers, or shilling a product etc). If in doubt, research the records these people have worked on, and listen to them to see if you actually like how they sound!


**Engineering/Mixing/Production**

Steve Albini / Electrical Audio: https://www.youtube.com/@ElectricalAudioOfficial

Making records with Eric Valentine: https://www.youtube.com/@mrwev

Just For The Record - Mixing/interview streams - https://www.youtube.com/@JFTRLive

Sol State - Clips from longer form streams by (mostly electronic and pop) producers - https://www.youtube.com/@SolStateMusic

Live With Matt Rad (focused around Instagram Live interviews, with a generous community on Discord - generally skewing towards pop)
Insta: https://www.instagram.com/livewithmattrad/
Discord: https://discord.com/invite/fcfEtxRbWT
Podcast on Spotify, Apple Music etc.
YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/@LivewithMattRad
YouTube Clips Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCs8ZKTveuxghTN-QaHFemsw

author: ehutton21
content: What’s the use cases for mono reverb vs stereo

author: ALXCPH
content: i was recently working on some guitar stuff. and it was a 3 guitar parts thing, guitars were panned L-C-R but the L & R reverbs was 25% towards the center in mono, and the main center guitar had a stereo verb. it ended up as a really cool blend. so basically   (Left guitar - 50%panned reverb) - (stereo reverb - Main Guitar - stereo reverb) - (50%panned reverb - Right guitar)

author: Will Melones
content: That sounds really neat. So the guitar in the center got all the width, and the ones on the sides got pulled inward a bit? I can’t wait to try this and hear it!

author: ALXCPH
content: if you want the sounds to blend even more, you can swap the LR reverbs so their are opposite to their source. But i preferred the L and R guitars having their reverb next to them a little closer to the center.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Maybe I’m misremembering. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ either way seems like a good use for a mono verb

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve used this kind of technique a couple of times: hard panned mono verb one side (nice if it’s characterful, springs n stuff), with a slap to the other. Or two disparate verbs. Depends on the space you have, and doesn’t always work, but it can be really nice - stole it from this record https://open.spotify.com/track/1EAuRuC7lIgIVLwXaZoHLo?si=kg-LqI93ThCWvAZ6Lyk7mg

Side note, I love the energy of the drums

author: BatMeckley
content:
There is a caveat here, in that Matt and I actually have an endgame here, which is keep the flow, don’t bog down the artist with nerd shit, and give them the best sounding track to work from. Where I disagree is the work to properly align it when it gets back, I’ve found it’s not too vibe killing to just have them copy paste my square wave down on to the end of their track. It’s one extra key command that most people can handle, and gives me (and the artist) the confidence that I’ve fully respected and captured their unique flow and timing. 

Right before I end up moving every word and syllable and breathe anyway.

author: ALXCPH
content:
My first option would always be to see if it was possible to sing it differently. If thats not possible, i would try to differentiate the two Lines where they overlap, maybe an eq or pan automation? Could be one disappears into the back with verb while the next one stays dry? If its still fucked, maybe just try and volume automate/shorten one of the lines. 

It really all depends on the song, and the importance of those Lines.

author: ALXCPH
content:
This really only happens when I song is written and recorded line for line at the same time. 

One a great way to really listen to a song is actually to play it with a guitar or a piano before recording it. It will really let you tune in on the core song and be able to judge it without all the production.

author: ALXCPH
content: And if it’s part of the energy, just lean into it and make it weird

author: ALXCPH
content: It all depends really

author: ALXCPH
content: You could let the ending of one pan out 10-20% during the word that over laps, while the the new sentence starts 10-20% out and pans inward

author: ALXCPH
content: Also making the end fade into the back with some verb or effect while the new one comes in dryer

author: ALXCPH
content: You could also make the ending of one slowly widen during the overlap while the next sentences is mono. I think subtlety is key with the genre you referenced.

author: ALXCPH
content: You could also think about doing two different vocal tones, so that every other sentence sits a little different tonally, leaning in on the call and response aspect

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So over in the Monitoring channel, someone new to the discord shared some knowledge, and I erroneously flagged the moderator to vet it. I feel like a dick, cause he immediately took the post down and then messaged me to ask what he did wrong. He didn’t do anything wrong, but it led me to think about why I immediately thought to flag instead of just engaging. 

Truth is, we’ve built a fairly structured culture over the past couple years, which can be hard to break into. Here’s what I shared, and I think it might be useful for newcomers and Old Hats alike:

author: Zack Hames
content:
Not exactly. But pickups make the biggest difference tone by a long mile. 

Like others have said, if a guitar plays well and feels good to you, then go for it and then put nice ass pickups in it, and you’re golden. 

Other big “sound” considerations are scale length,  bridge style/material and nut material. Not to mention the strings themselves. 

Lighter guitars actually resonate / have more sustain usually, for obvious physics reasons that people ignored for a long time.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Tape Machine question:

When people run to tape machines now, are they mostly just running through the electronics of the machines or are they really recording it to tape? How much of the sound is the machine vs the tape itself?

author: Eric Martin
content: I think it would be for the sound of the tape and machine itself, live printing off the repro head into tools

author: Eric Martin
content: for others it could be about the limitations also, only 16 or 25 tracks, waiting for rewind to playback all the negative things that drew us all to digital would be the reason to go back to tape to me, the romantic ideal and nostalgia of yesterday knowing it won’t be a “modern” record

author: Edward Rivera
content: I think if you're going from the repro head into tools you're cutting off a significant of information based on the sample rate

author: Adam Thein
content: The stuff above nyquist?

author: Edward Rivera
content: In photography we use drum scanners that can scan even the oldest film and print them at incredible resolution (there's that word again) but those scanners are useless on say, a shot on a digital camera from 1999 at 12MP. Would it not be the same idea to want to preserve the resolution of tape instead of baking in a session at whatever sample rate it was ran at ?

author: Adam Thein
content:
Huh yeah I understand - but for what I’m using it for I don’t need anything above nyquist personally, I’m just using it as an effect not for tracking

To be clear my use case is in mixing/post production - running tracks captured at 44.1 or 48k most often, using tape for compression/color/distortion and then bringing back in digitally at the same sample rate as the session.

author: Zack Hames
content:
@cian riordan @Adam Thein @Eric Martin thanks for the fantastic responses. This all makes sense. 

The monitoring the repro-head and recording back to digital all in one step note: This is what I am curious about. There's an Otari MX5050 at the studio that I want to mess around with and we have tons of tapes around the studio i'm sure i could use. 

SO, Can you sort of passively have the tape machine going without having to operate it actively and just use pro tools, all while getting the tape sound? Like a hardware insert or simply bringing it in and monitoring? 

I didn't grow up with Tape, but I want to explore the sounds because so many of my fav sounding records used tape. Many also DIDN'T, but I feel like i've got to figure this out for myself.

author: Adam Thein
content: Yes - set it to record and you’ve got about 25 minutes to just work before you need to rewind.

author: Zack Hames
content: That's awesome! so you're not even actually recording onto the tape, just monitoring the repro head while it runs. It didn't seem like it could be that simple but it clearly is. that's dope!

author: Zack Hames
content: Ah okay, so you just rewind and it records over what was there for the 25 min or so at 15ips.

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Shift + ?**: Open *Info View*.

This will open a help window in the lower-left corner and reveal descriptions of everything that they move their mouse cursor over. Including any relevant key commands.

I would put that at the top of their list, because it will enable them to educate themselves as they go.

author: Slow Hand
content:
@river I would also mention that they can find the key command for most tasks within the dropdown menus (red arrow)

@Maxim If you ever forget the key command to hide *Info View* you can just click the little triangle/arrow in the lower-left corner (yellow arrow)

author: Slow Hand
content:
My most-used commands are:

Cmd + Opt + B: Open/close browser.
Cmd + Opt + L: Open/close bottom track window.
Shift + Tab: Toggle between *Instrument View* and *Clip View* in the bottom track window.

I'm a habitual window toggler. If I'm not using the window it gets hidden immediately. I probably wouldn't mention it to a newbie, but it's probably a nice reminder for more seasoned users.

author: bobby k
content:
got a couple noob questions about mixers having label rates, still not sure i totally get it. 

what's the argument for having a label rate vs. an indie rate? are you not doing the same service regardless? is indie rate technically a discount? the one argument that makes total sense is that an indie rate is discounted because you don't have to spend 7+ months chasing down the payment through a label's bureaucracy. but conceptually is there any other reason for it? also, is that always the case or do some labels have more respectable turnarounds on payment. 

i have one rate and that's what I value my service. I don't see why it matters who is footing the bill. makes sense with production and points discrepancies, but mixing? huh?

author: bobby k
content: yea totally! i get the discrepancy on flexibility with the rate, that makes total sense. I've also seen some people do a discount for anyone that can pay up front. like 10% or something. no clue if a label has ever worked out for that though, they take so long to fill an invoice it borders on disrespectful

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: For me, my rate depends on how quick something needs to be turned around and how intense I have to be with delivery (different versions, alts, stems, etc)

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: I’ll always do the same level of work regardless of rate though

author: bobby k

author: bobby k

content: I see the WA73 has a DI...have you plugged in a guitar to it directly to see if you can get signal at your EVO from your WA73 to make sure it's not the TRS to XLR adapter coming off the EVO causing the issue?

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’d take a look at the interface software - are the outputs to 3+4 turned up in the audient software?  Are you getting visual feedback of signal hitting those channels outside Ableton?

I’d remove as many variables as possible and test each part of the chain individually.  Try connecting the output of the Evo 8 ch 3 back into the Evo 8 input 4 without the 273 first and make sure it isn’t a software issue, then check the analog connections one at a time if that works.  My guess is a software thing with the Audient mixer.

author: Rollmottle
content: If you can get signal on input 4 then it’s something around the software on output 3. You double check that you have the outputs activated in Ableton?

author: Rollmottle
content: i'd also remove the external audio effect in Ableton as a variable next and try to just send signal out from a track and receive it on another track.

author: Rollmottle
content: i reckon this might be where your problem is

author: Rollmottle
content: are you using the mic pre or the DI on the 273?

author: Rollmottle
content: yes, but how are you getting in to the 273? you mentioned a TRS to XLR adapter, but the XLR on the 273 is the mic input. TRS to TRS Line In on the back of the 273 with the Line button on the front pressed in should get you signal back at Ableton (TRS Line Out from 273 to TRS Line In on the Evo)

author: Rollmottle
content: you have another TRS cable you can use on the return from the 273 back to the Evo?

author: Rollmottle
content: same behavior on Channel 1 and 2 on the 273?

author: Rollmottle
content: have you taken Ableton entirely out of the equation. sound source into 273 back into Evo. does it show up in the Evo mixer?

author: Rollmottle
content: you tried the other inputs on the Evo?

author: Rollmottle
content: you checked your Mac Audio Midi to make sure the inputs aren't muted?

author: Rollmottle
content: this is what this channel is for (not making you feel stupid 😂  )

author: Rollmottle
content: make sure you're not sending the track that's sending output on 3 to the monitor in Ableton

author: Rollmottle
content: no problem! you mean monitor whatever is coming in from the 273?

author: Rollmottle
content: try it without the external audio effect again...1 pitch track and one catch track to see if you can hear the input at the monitor

author: Rollmottle
content: i'm not too familar with the external audio effect module in ableton...i always use 2 tracks to do what you're trying to do because it seems more flexible.

author: Rollmottle
content: completely dry would be your original signal. completely wet will be nothing but the 273.

author: Rollmottle
content: https://help.ableton.com/hc/en-us/articles/360005113200-Using-external-audio-effects#h_79cb3127-5b39-4d3a-bcdd-4e8a89e7ec23 this describes the setup in Ableton for this

author: Adam Thein
content: Any luck @! Andy ! where you left off?  I passed out early last night.

author: Adam Thein
content:
One thing I noticed is that this video shows you are looking at the mix for Outputs 1+2 on your Evo- what you hear from your monitors I assume - make sure you check out your mix on outputs 3+4 by clicking that on the right hand side of the software mixer.  You probably got feedback because input channel 4 in the Evo software is turned up on output 3+4 mix.  If you only plan to use outputs 3+4 for hardware loops, make sure Mac 3 and Mac 4 are turned up to unity (0) and Mac 1+2 are turned all the way down, and I’d turn down all the mic inputs  so you don’t create any feedback loops.

If that’s all set up correctly I’m stumped for now!

author: Rollmottle
content: At 100% wet on the external effect module, you should be hearing nothing but the WA as long as the signal you’re sending out to it isn’t going to your monitors.

content:
When you get a chance could you send new screenshots of where you are at @! Andy !? I’m not sure what has changed and what hasn’t - I feel like you must be close.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Have you tried a Google search? Maybe he's discussed it in an interview or a video. That's pretty specific information that we're not likely to know. 

If we *do* happen to know the exact setting for a specific song, it's important to understand that these settings can change on each record, depending on what the vocal needs. So his settings may be different from song to song.

I think a more illuminating question you could ask is something like "How do I get the vocal sound from this specific song that I like"?

It all starts with a well-written song. That’s the foundation of a hit record.

author: Slow Hand
content:
It sounds like a delay unit with a *freeze* function that captures the audio buffer and makes it repeat infinitely without decay or degradation. Soundtoys *Primal Tap* has this feature. You might be able to cheat it using a regular delay unit if you set the feedback amount to 100% and disable the filtering or modulation  in the feedback loop so that it doesn't degrade.

Also, that echo is drenched in a large reverb.

author: Slow Hand
content: Yup! *Delay* has it. If you click the infinity button (circled in red) it is the same functionality. It will freeze the buffer at a length equivalent to your delay time and not decay.

author: Slow Hand
content:
**Some More (cause you've got me thinking):**

Kick off the song with a bang.
Write a deliberate introduction. (This is big. It will give your record propulsion, confidence and purpose instead of dropping the listener into the middle.)
End the record in a conclusive and unmistakable way.

Everybody plays as soft as they can.
Everybody plays as loud as they can.
The louder you play the simpler the part has to be.
The softer you play the faster the part has to be.

Role play. Choose an emotion/mindset and embody that as the player: melancholy, furious, chaotic, childlike, meek.

Instrumental fills every few bars.
Take a solo. A short one.
Make some noise!

Listen to your song at different tempos.
Do a dramatic speed up or slow down - This will show you new aspects of your groove.

Unexpected part entrance.
Intro solo before the band enters.

Only two instrumental parts allowed. Be minimal and sparse.
Write a melody starting with the kick pattern.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: But he did, and I managed to get the basic production in order, (drums from @JustinLeu helped a ton,) and ready for vocals on monday. Finished the production on Tuesday and hit notes this morning early before packing.

author: NoahNeedleman

author: Adam Thein
content:
I'd get in touch with a music lawyer who can help you make sure you have everything in place to collect all your back end - there's a lot of revenue sources you'll want to make sure you are collecting from.

Often you'll have had a producer agreement in place and a letter of direction that will be sent to the distributor/label so that if you have points on the master you'll be paid directly from them.

You'll also need to have a PRO/Publisher in place to collect songwriting royalties, and many folks have in place a publisher deal or publisher admin deal to collect those royalties on your behalf in exhange for a % of your royalty.  In my case I am set up with BMI in the US as my PRO and Publisher and have an admin pub deal with Sentric to collect in territories outside the US.

Also you'll want to be set up with SoundExchange to collect digital performance royalties (SiriusXM, iHeart, Pandora).  This often also involves the letter of direction that is kicked off with your producer agreement.

I'm probably forgetting something but I'd highly recommend talking with a music lawyer to get things set up and working for you.

author: Adam Thein
content: Also I don't know much about it but I think you can use the MLC to help collect mechanical royalties in the US if you don't have a pub or admin pub deal to do so.

author: Will Melones
content: We always talk about delivering mix stems that add up to match the mix, but what alt mixes do you have mastered, and how do you manage the discrepancy between the deliverables that go to a ME and the ones that just have your mix bus processing? Particularly those of you doing label work

author: cian riordan
content: Oh fuck yea, MM forever! I usually just trim the input of my final limiter (almost always the Ozone maximizer) 5dB and call it a day. All of the compression/limiting/clipping thats happening on various busses beforehand stay the same. I try to not lean on the final limiting stage to heavily in building the 'loudenss' of the mix, but I know that's not the case for everybody. If there was an instance where it was really part of the sound, I'd just leave it and send it off. Any mastering engineer worth their salt should be OK working with whatever you send them. If there are glaring issues, they're likely to bring it up... but most mixers I know don't even peel back the limiter a little... so the loudness is fully baked into the mix.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: The “send me no bus compressor” aesthetic (I have expensive ones!) thing is severely out of date

author: Zack Hames
content:
Prophet 6 is like the be all end all for hardware synths. If I could recommend anyone that’s serious about synths or production In General and can afford it, this is the move. 

Otherwise, I’d go quality over quantity. Get a knobby analog synth that’s easy to make sounds quickly. You’ll have more fun if you’re used to more tactile instruments.

Having a digital synth with a bunch of menus that’s “more powerful” (3+ oscillators, several LFO’s, tons of polyphony) isn’t any fun when you can’t change the sounds quickly,easily, or intuitively. 

Korg MS20 was the first synth I fell in love with. Felt like playing guitar or something. Like an actual instrument.

Prophet 6 and OB-6 are incredible. If I had to pick one for myself it would be the OB-6. But the prophet is super versatile and usable in any style more so than the OB6.

I’d take an analog mono synth with knob per function over a powerful digital synth with menus

author: Zack Hames
content: That said, You could buy a prophet 6 and be done. Straight up.

author: bobby k
content: Let me preface by saying nothing tangible has got me feeling down or discouraged. In fact I think I'm in the best season of my life so far and it feels like everything is going right (aside: aren't you more likely to self sabotage when things are good than when they are bad?) to zoom out a little bit, i already know the answer. I'm doing too much at once, spreading myself thin beyond enjoyment. in the grit of a transition and it's clear where I'm going but I have no frame of reference for the timeline. A few years ago, I was mid-20s, in a band on a major, had roommates & cheap rent, and a chess app addiction. i was still a "professional" but things were extremely simple. in short, left the band, spent a few years mixing much more than producing, and now am swinging back that way. I'm about to turn 30, I have a mortgage, a (semi) dependent, my first real studio, an intern to set an example for, 5ish mixing clients at any moment, producing for 3 artists and co-prod/consulting on 2 other projects, playing occasionally in any of 4 different bands, and producing/recording some live performances (as well as starting a YT channel in this lane). In my experience at least, it really seems like something shifted at the top of this year, and I hate to say it but part of the fault is TikTok (is the rest of the fault mine?). Everything is urgent to everyone and nothing informs each other or oscillates together. It feels like a clock is constantly going "tick, tock, tick, tock" and the anxiety I once had over money is shifted completely towards my time management. Every time I look away from my phone I have 30 new texts. I think I'm crushing it in my professional demands but I don't know that I'm being the person I want to be for my friends, family and partner. I don't know that I'm setting a good example to this intern. I don't know that I'm there to take care of myself all the way.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This isn’t for everyone, but a few big mixers like this technique. 

After you clean & clip gain, (RX is super helpful for plosives, mouth noises, de essing,) this is one of the only ways I know to take a vocal from raw to sounding like it was tracked well. 

The concept is mostly about balancing a spitty compressor like an 1176 and a slower/warmer compressor like a Fairchild, and then bussing both of those to a new aux, then eq’ing compressing saturating de essing like that was the vocal you weee given in the first place.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
If you want vocals to sound expensive, COMPRESS THE SHIT OUT OF ‘EM. 

You don’t wanna hear the pump, but you wanna hear every nuance in the performance.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Compressing like this introduces a new set of problems with esses & breaths, so its tradeoffs.

I'll take this to biz talk if it belongs there, but it genuinely feels like a newbie question so here it goes. 

how the hell do you get a label to send you your royalties? I've been on a month+ long quest running in circles with UMG's "royalty support" or whatever it's called, and they have been impressively unhelpful. Trying to chase down an imaginary dollar amount on 20+ songs I've produced, or at least speak to the person who's like tracking that information & recoupment and all that to get like any sort of window into what's going on. Artist's mgmt and A&Rs have kind of been dead-ends. Anybody have a good UMG person they'd be comfortable doing an intro? Or any tips otherwise?

author: Adam Thein
content: Do you have a lawyer or manager friend that can step in and help?  Might be worth taking this off your plate if the amount is significant enough to offset.  Or a go between if your relationship is good with that person.  I was super fortunate that the artist’s manager helped me get royalty flowing but it took about 14 months of following up.

author: bobby k
content: Considering looping in my lawyer for sure. I bet he's got somebody over there he already knows so that's a no brainer. but was hoping to avoid that if possible. currently self-managed as my former manager is transitioning careers and wouldn't wanna take him on a potential 14 month side quest haha

author: Adam Thein
content: Yeah, really going to be up to you if the amount of royalties we're talking about is worth getting a hand with.  Otherwise positive persistence.  I just had a calendar reminder to follow up around the 5th of every month, no escalation, just politely checking in.

author: cian riordan
content: Most monitor controllers have analog circuitry and that will be the sonic bottle neck… some just sound cleaner than others, not to mention stepped attenuators vs potentiometers and how they balance L/R signals and eventually shift over time.

author: cian riordan
content: The I/O can also be quite different between them — some will have more analog inputs vs digital, etc. others will have better features for integrating subs and additional sets of speakers. Mine even had a USB DAC and a phone preamp which makes it a real Swiss Army knife in the studio.

Always always always edit things before adding new things. @BoozleBAM

author: Edward Rivera
content: I’ve had to work on tape machines I didn’t know, consoles I didn’t know, less than ideal mic lockers, unfamiliar / bad rooms, and even unfamiliar DAWs. But ultimately these were tests of my character and how I respond under duress.

author: Edward Rivera
content: My favourite record has no crossfades and can hear it everywhere

author: Edward Rivera
content: What does “right on” mean to you

author: Edward Rivera
content: Write down the things that require your attention, and write down their possible solutions. It’s good to put those things in language

author: Edward Rivera
content: As for this, I’ve used these two methods together; I’ll slip edit things where they need to be, and use time stretching to bridge the inevitable gaps made in the audio (like extending cymbal hits to the next beat)

author: Edward Rivera
content: Also, take a break from it

author: Edward Rivera
content: Like, take at least a week, definitely more, without touching these songs

author: Edward Rivera
content: It sounds really shit I know. But it’s only going to _help you_

author: Edward Rivera
content: Where as all this obsessiveness is only getting in the way of what you ultimately want

author: Edward Rivera
content: I think it’s great that you’re detail oriented. But there’s a difference between being astute and being lost in the weeds

author: Edward Rivera
content: So the things I’m saying are meant to get you out of that headspace and recalibrate, because _that_ is what’s going to make you happy with your record, and get it over the finish line

author: Edward Rivera
content: I don’t think crossfades is the right rabbit hole to be going down

author: Edward Rivera
content: Just set the crossfades, make sure it’s not affecting your transients, and carry on. Not much else to it

author: Edward Rivera
content: Zoom in to your regions and set those crossfades to happen before the transients. If I make a cut to a drum and move it, I’ll almost always drag the region back out to the left and give myself the slack to make my crossfades

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I set mine at 10ms, easy to tell if I’ve gone too far with even one nudge. Then I’ll set it to 5ms, and go back

And yes since we are in the millisecond range try not to get too hung up on it. I break out this tool if there’s a late snare hit but I don’t go messing around with an entire groove unless it’s noticeable 

The longer you spend on this the less objective you can be come

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I’m butchering the exact wisdom, but it was said to me that often when nearing the finish line of a record, it’s common practice for people to compile a list of all the reasons why the audience won’t like their record. It’s now their duty to tend to these things and not consider their work complete until all these little nuisances have, one by one, been crossed of this holy list…et voila ! It’s _perfect_ !

FWIW I wouldn’t want to consume any body of work made from this perspective

author: Edward Rivera
content:
I would say pay less attention. When you’re in “hunting mode” you’re queued in on to everything except the part that matters: the music. 

Listen to the song without asking yourself “what else can I get outta here” I think that sets you up for wrong moves, more delays, etc…if there’s something that needs your attention it should be somewhat obvious and a bit basic, not some tiny clinical move that will suddenly open up the record. 

And yet, in some cases even _that_ is true.

author: Edward Rivera
content: Listen more. Hyper-focusing and listening aren’t the exact same thing

author: Edward Rivera
content: And to add…the more and more you do this, the more you’ll reach for the fader first

author: Edward Rivera
content: There’s no Grammy for how _much_ engineering is done to a record

author: Edward Rivera
content: And he exhausted quite a few things before reaching for it

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: yes, you paid for infinite insert slots in reaper, you have to use infinite insert slots in reaper /s

author: Edward Rivera
content: Also, simplify your objectives. Rather than ask yourself “what frequency do I need to zap” start with things like “could this be brighter ? Could this be darker ? Could this be louder ? Quieter ?” You’d be surprised how effective those simple broad stroke moves are compared to surgical cuts

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here’s gain staging in a nut shell: don’t clip. In pro tools I try to keep all my faders at 0 or below. Seems to play nice and I don’t ever go back at the end of my mix to push everything down.

Make sure you aren’t clipping within plugins either. Fabfilter pro-Q 3 is notoriously nasty sounding when clipped.

author: Zack Hames
content: Gain staging mattered a lot back in tape days for noise floor. Less of an issue now.

author: spectrummasters
content:
What I get from my sub groups is , once I’ve balanced gainstaged and shaped the tone of the individual elements of a mix , they arrive into groups . Then at the group level I can create parallels , do group automations and create more or less crosstalk between the instruments at a group level (via side chaining comps . Gates etc ) I like to do tiny side chains between the kick the bass and the music bus depending on how I want the groups to play together . I’ll do a tiny side chain between the vocal bus and the music and drums groups . (I’m talking 0.5db   , broad q At pertinent frequencies ) this isn’t corrective it’s just to create play/movement at a group level . 

My groups usually are kick . Drums . 808/bass . Music . Vocals . Fx .

author: spectrummasters
content: I think of my groups as the glue and density / loudness stage

author: spectrummasters
content: Like Zak Higgins said the other day about clipping

author: spectrummasters
content: Groups can serve as a good place to clip/limit and spare the 2 bus loading

author: spectrummasters
content: I tend to think in terms of channel level > group level > 2bus

author: spectrummasters
content: As Noah said though , keep solving problems and you’ll build your best workflow bro

author: spectrummasters
content: Also the other cool thing I find about groups is

author: spectrummasters
content: There’s often one element of a mix that I find just wants to bypass all the groups and hit the stereo bus immediately . And often is the thing that really brings the mix to life . Contrast !

author: Zack Hames
content: Not clipping. I don’t care as long as it’s not clipping before processing

author: Zack Hames

author: Zack Hames
content:
That’s why I do the faders at 0
Or below. It all lands in the master fader really well. If I start pushing faders up (fader creep) I start to clip the master

author: Zack Hames

author: spectrummasters
content: Ya , fwiw : I like (in Logic Pro ) faders at zero , peaking at -8 in the channels . Touch the faders for balance . Usually peak about -3 in sub groups  buses . Sub group master faders all at -5 from start of mix . Usually ending up about -2 peak in masterbus , 2 bus comp threshold / input gain will adjust to what this number is to get the 3 db peak max I’m looking for usually

author: spectrummasters
content: Again @BoozleBAM I’m not saying copy me , just sharing how I approach it for myself

author: spectrummasters
content: There will be others with more expertly calibrated and clever workflows

author: spectrummasters
content: Just wanted to share a sense of how for me I know where things should be for my own workflow at the variouss “gain “stages to be “on track “ for your final levels

author: spectrummasters
content: Once you get your own little working set up you kinda don’t need to work so hard on it anymore and can just have fun mixing

author: spectrummasters
content: Oh fr yeah . The drums peaks are controlled at the group bus stage and then that group fader is down -5 …so that’s my headroom on the 2 bus

author: spectrummasters
content: On average I’d say 1.5 db peak gr reduction of the mix is happening in neutron compressor , on the 2 bus just for a little control  and it’s 50% dry/wet .

author: Rollmottle

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: They all come from having made all these mistakes over the years haha

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
ExFAT has given me problems so I avoid it. It seems to work for some other folks but these days my go to is a SSD running APFS. I gravitate towards the Samsung T7, they’ve been super reliable. Avoid SanDisk, but I think there are some other folks using things from other brands like Crucial.

Hard drives are super susceptible to damage and weird mechanical failure when moving them around, and they’re much slower. Do yourself a favor and work from a solid state (and keep everything backed up in multiple places)

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: That unsafe ejecting part can really mess up a hard drive because the final writing of some files (even if it seems like any transfers are finished) can get interrupted, leading to corruption. It may not even be apparent immediately

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: And always operate under the presumption that any drive can fail at any time

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: Open up disk utility with the new drive connected and erase/format the new drive with whatever name you want and the APFS file format. Look up on Apple’s site how to use disk utility if you get stumped

author: Bryan DiMaio

author: cian riordan
content: Since you’re layering evething up yourself, there’s value in treating every section differently to give you the most control. If that seems weird as a novice, and you want to play through the song, there’s no harm in doing that either. You can always separate the sections down the road and treat them accordingly.

author: Edward Rivera
content: Id leave it up to the guitarist. If it’s an instance where they’d prefer to run through the tune front to back, we do some work to make sure that there’s no crazy spikes or dips in level with each pedal and that the dynamics of the performance sound as they should

author: cian riordan
content: Let’s say you want the verse to sound thinner or quieter, and you want the chorus to sound thicker and wider… you can do some of this with the performance and your sweet pedal action… but you’ll be able to take it further by separating the sections of the song (verse guitars in one track, pre chorus in another, etc). This way you can effect and mix them accordingly. Just giving you more control and helps the song have more dynamics since it’s just one guitar take throughout.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Phase shift on a single sound is rarely (if at all) noticeable. 

Phase shift on a sound becomes important when that sound interacts with a second sound. It’s about the relationship between them because it changes the constructive and destructive interference (phase cancellation) that occurs between the two sounds.

There may be a few instances where it matters in the context of a single sound, but I’ll let more qualfied people chime in on that.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Phase coherence as it relates to speakers vs how an eq shifts phase within a single track in mixing are two entirely different worlds. Not worth considering how they relate. 

For what it’s worth, I almost never pay attention to how an eq effect phase except for when filtering out low end, as it actually does create a resonant peak just above the filter point. 

Otherwise the only question that really needs answering is “is this better for the track?”

author: NoahNeedleman
content: It might be worth unpacking a little more, like @Rollmottle was getting at, the idea of having a  “philosophy of mixing.” I’m gonna move that conversation over to #👩🍳mixing-talk tho

author: David Fuller
content: Nah, the Harman Curve is a headphone tonality preference curve. Not much to do with why mids get cut a lot

author: cian riordan
content: I very rarely hear or notice phase shift on single source EQ moves. If I do, it's often on low end or sub material... especially kick drums or 808s. I'll find they punch a different way... sometimes good, sometiems bad... so I tend to be a little more judicious with moves down there.

author: David Fuller
content: The reason I see that mids get cut a lot is that it leaves room for more "lead" instruments or voices

author: David Fuller
content: That and not everything can have a ton of energy in that region

author: David Fuller
content: they just know "it sounds good" and they build a framework of what they *think* is happening to explain it

author: peterlabberton
content: Funny you mention this—I’ve also never been particularly keyed in to phase shifts in a single source, but I do often try a high pass on a drum buss to see if it gets the punch of the kick to hit in a better way. Assuming it’s not adding tons of gain… my best guess is that’s just the phase shift playing with the envelope of the attack? I think this feels obvious to me but I guess I’ve never explicitly thought “that’s because of phase shift”, more just “that’s because of the high pass”.

author: peterlabberton

author: David Fuller

author: David Fuller
content: where the best descriptor is "phase soup"

author: spectrummasters
content: I’m fascinated with phase and waves . I expect this might all be familiar to you but it seems there’s some handy info about phase and audio here https://mycourses.aalto.fi/pluginfile.php/666520/course/section/128564/Jon%20Fagerstr%C3%B6m_1929997_assignsubmission_file_AAT_Seminar_paper_Phase_Equalization_JF_FINAL.pdf?time=1558421096226#:~:text=Phase%20equalizers%20are%20filters%20that,response%20of%20a%20given%20system.

author: spectrummasters
content: Do you have izotope eq ? There’s a setting in the preferences that says something like “show all curves “ click on it and it adds a time display into the graphic on the gui

author: spectrummasters
content: You can then go into the little sidebar on the tab for each eq point and you ll see a slider that allows you to move the eq point from linear to minimum phase

author: spectrummasters
content: It will also show you simultaneously on the time graphic what part of the signal is being delayed (or not )

author: spectrummasters
content: It’s an interesting tool to be able to slide between eq types and not have to switch them as in FabFilter .

author: spectrummasters
content:
I also use SSL’s X phase a lot , as much to investigate how many different ways one can adjust phase on a source and to listen to the interplay between sounds . I’ll usually always employ it on low end elements at the moment , just as much as an educational tool as anything . You can do much much more than flip the phase 

And finally phase rotators . I got really into these . RX has one . And the manufacture who make that teote plug in make one and Maat I believe .

author: spectrummasters
content: I ve used them all to just really investigate

author: spectrummasters
content: Another one is to take a sine wave at 100 hz and put in a high pass filter and start moving it around and look at the consequent response post filter on the sine wave

author: spectrummasters
content: Re Jons point that you referred to , I can remember watching that one but I don’t remember the wording

author: spectrummasters
content: I recall it as him pointing out that although we look at the Hz number on an eq we should be aware that it may have a pronounced effect on our perception of an area of audio elsewhere . I’ve heard this described as the yin yang effect . So if on the master I feel it’s too bright , I could choose to work in the low end with boosts in a certain place   As much as cuts in the high end , in order to affect that perception of brightness

content: But , sorry I digress

author: spectrummasters

Audio and electrical engineering and their marriage and understanding of one to inform the other  is probably my main fascination in life these days (along with the maths and physics of it ) .

author: bobby k
content: Producing/recording my first rock track & would love any tips on getting the drums right! I know Cian already crushed a LFTWR tutorial in here I should revisit that discusses parallel saturation n such. We tracked today, got 441s on kick and snare top, sm7b’s on snare bottom and hat, LCR overheads with my 251 in center and some flat pencils L/R, M201 on each tom, some random Omni EV mic on crotch and a stereo ribbon in the room (r88 clone). Room is rather dead but it’s 600 sq feet so we still get some life out of it when rocking. Refs are like anything Steve Albini has touched, as well as that latest Bully record. I’m mostly working on soft pop Americana type stuff so this is a very fun new adventure. So far really digging slamming the left right overheads with saturn2 transformer, may sample replace kick and snare but just with samples we took at the end. Any tips on making that shit slap in a crunchy modern way would be appreciated ❤️

author: Zack Hames
content: -Destroy the crotch mic with decapitator and blend

author: Zack Hames
content: You can Key the kick or snare tracks to a gate on the room mics to get more emphasis on the shells vs the cymbals. Sometimes this can help avoid washy crappy room sound. R88 is one of my favs for rooms tho

author: Zack Hames
content: Also…compromise perfect fidelity for energy/emotion/intensity. I’ve been leaning on that a lot lately with success. Maybe there’s a little too much high mid. But when you remove it, it’s lifeless. Try to find that balance of aggressive and rockin’ but easy to listen to

author: Zack Hames
content: Also, if the music is supposed to be listened to loud….do some EQ moves with the speakers up a bit. I find EQ moves translate better when I mix with some decent volume. Mixing quiet makes everything so out of balance for me especially low end and high end

(i'm always chasing the "golden hour" drums)

author: spectrummasters
content:
….SSL comp on the 2 bus , anti vocal pumping strategies . 
TLDR , I love the SSL Bus comp on the 2 bus . 10ms attack usually …release program dependent (not usually auto ) and for about 2 -3 db gain . I got rid of MB compression on my mixbus and do earlier . So , I love the character of the SSL comp as a finisher , glue etc . Only problem . I find it impossible sometimes to avoid vocal pumping . Are there any old vet strategies for this ? I’ve tried pinning the vocal on its bus pre 2 bus in an effort to anchor it in the mix , but the dynamics I lose in the vocal by so doing still don’t really seem to earn me much improvement against the pumping of the SSL

author: spectrummasters
content: I’d love to find a clever mitigation

author: spectrummasters
content: Oh of course !! Right . Send my music , drums and bass to a bus , glue it there then send it to the 2 bus to meet up with the vocal and just the final  limiter . Brilliant. That’ll give me the little bit of pumping off the low end I want

author: spectrummasters
content: Thanks Bryan, funnily enough it’s that action / pump coming off the low end I want , but didn’t want it pulling down the vocal . I think ed s gifted me the answer

author: spectrummasters
content:
Yay 

This mix can now arrive at perfection

author: spectrummasters
content: I like a parallel for all my music elements that goes to a pitch shifted (+12) microshift , little decap and into a verb . I’ll feather that in a breakdown or chorus etc . Lovely for a little unheard icing

author: spectrummasters
content: Vocals and BVs have separate buses and vocal fx and all other FX have a separate bus .

author: spectrummasters
content: Like you I find this gives me so many ways to create the cross talk I want between elements . Eg . I don’t like side chaining a kick to a bass at channel level but I do like my different buses to duck each other a tiny amount (0.5 -1db max ) in pertinent hz ranges pre 2 bus

author: spectrummasters
content: Verbs at the mo , usually three or four  . Liquidsonics bricasti small room a , super plate , capitol chambers , trueverb . And I use a Valhalla hall for bvs .

author: spectrummasters
content: What I did not have …..an instrumental bus ! 💙

author: spectrummasters
content: So , yep thanks to Ed , seems obvious in retrospect . Previously I’d key the side chain of the SSL from my kick and have it on the drums : and one on the music bus . As I’ve moved the SSL onto the 2 bus now , that’s where I got stuck for a mo

author: spectrummasters
content: FWIW , I think for me it’s only been once I’ve really been able to hear compression that any bussing I have done made any sense lol . When we start mixing there’s all this , what’s your chain , what’s your template , side chain , don’t side chain …..and you can’t really do anything with any of that info until you’ve spent ages learning to hear the character of compression imho

author: spectrummasters
content: This has been the big part of my love affair with the SSL comp . It’s so powerful at shaping a mix , but subtly (as well as blatantly if desired ). Love it !

author: Zack Hames
content:
PMC twotwo8’s were a step in the right direction for me of what was possible. PMC 6-2’s have been “easy mode” compared to any other speaker I’ve ever used. (Typical offerings from Yamaha, Genelec, Dynaudio, JBL and some other brands like Emotiva). 

I’ve never used ATC’s, mums, or Neumann. But at a certain level it’s about what works for you. 

I find the entry level Kali’s to be the best bang for your buck early on. If you’re on Yamaha HS8’s or KRK’s and NOT happy with your results, id consider them. Everyone I’ve suggested them to ( mostly musicians and producers) love them and whenever I hear them I don’t feel like I’m in some weird EQ’d hellscape

author: spectrummasters
content: I’m wondering about general principles of mixing a drum kit , from the perspective of experienced engineers ……when it comes to the particular drums ( kick in and out for example ) which are close mic’d with two different mics, when it comes to the tiny timing differences of when that drum beat arrives at the kick in ….and  the kick out …..are you on principle , leaving that phase relationship captured on the consequent drum multitrack ….or are we on principle aligning those kick in and and out tracks so the transients can align bang on with no (millisecond ) out of phase relationship . My thoughts are I want those kicks hitting spot on together , but then I’m corrupting the phase relationship of the bleed in the kick out to the rest of the kit . So are y’all then chasing this phase shifting around the kit multitracks and trying to build a drum mix that represents the sounds as though they all arrived at the close mics at the same instant …..or are these discrepancies of the sound travelling different distances to the close mics ……to be preserved ? I’ve experimented and will continue to do so , but I wonder if there’s a consensus principle around this time / distance to phase aspect of recording and mixing drums ?

author: spectrummasters
content: I’m thinking about not wanting the speaker to be trying to push and pull at the same time on playback if these time / phase relationships are left “as it happened “ during recording .

author: spectrummasters
content: Thank you Edward . I totally follow what you’re saying there . With regards to polarity …..I’m feeling confident in making the correct choices , and yes the delay lines / nudging tracks on close mics feels like I’m staring into the abyss . I’m happy with the sound of the kits I’ve been working on lately , but they are ok to feel “live “ and a bit looser . I’m anticipating wanting to get that super tight really punchy / dialed in kit sound I hear on some contemporary records at the moment. Can one achieve that without nudging / delay lines I suppose is what I’m pondering ?

author: cian riordan
content: Pros and cons, like anything else. Open back tend to have a more neutral response… almost closer to being on speakers. Less fatiguing. Downside is lack of isolation from outside world, lack of low/high end “hype”. Neither are a panacea and both will have their issues with translation to the outside world. I can mix in headphones because I’ve mixed in good sounding rooms as built up good practices - with good results - for 20 years. But it isn’t my ideal. I would almost always trust a decent sounding — even unideal room before solely relying on them.

content:
So, try to keep some things the same, change smaller things.

If you do left side with a les paul a Marshall and an sm57, then the right side with a strat through a twin with a ribbon mic, it’s gonna sounding fucking weird and disconnected. I find that to be not the move.

I often double track with the exact same rig, I don’t care about the “phase” argument. It just feels tight and huge to me. I may use a different boost pedal or something super subtle.

My fav guitar mics from brightest to darkest 

sm57 for classic, biting, bright, aggressive guitars 
md441 for huge but smooth high end
beyerdynamic m160 for extra mids or smoother highs 
RCA 74B for fender style amps 
Coles 4038 for extra bright or harsh amps

author: Slow Hand
content:
Probably not responsive at all, or only noticeable on less extreme settings. 

Granular synthesis is something that tends to obscure what's played into it. It takes a small recording of what you play and then it chops it into little pieces and rearranges them or modulates the playback speed. So the nuances of what you play often get smeared and obscured. Subtlety like vibrato tends to get lost.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
In the UK there are specialist providers for musicians and producers with studios. You submit a spreadsheet of your inventory including the value it would cost to replace each item (I update annually based on reverb / eBay current prices), and the location of cover needed (just in studio, or maybe on the road nationally or internationally if you play shows too). 

Not sure if the same in the US but I’d imagine there’s similar.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: You know. Skipping insurance is always positive Expected Value, (so long as you can afford the replacement cost), at the expense of greater variance.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I don't want to clog the channel, but very quickly (and this is quite an oversimplification): If you have a 10% chance of incurring a $10,000 loss, then your EV is -$1000 (-$10000 * 0.1). So you'll lose $1k on average, but in actual real life it's a binary outcome: either -$10k or -$0. Insurance mitigates that variance, but not for free. So you don't just pay $1000, it gets marked up, and  you might pay the insurance company $1200 to insure against that $10,000 risk. The numbers are very very simplified to make the point briefly.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I'm not Conor, but I'll jump in: That Mr. Beast document is illuminating because it drives home how single-minded, clear, and focused he is on his objective. So the remarkable part - for me - is that he's not trying to make great videos. He's trying to make great *Youtube* videos. Videos that perform exceptionally within the Youtube ecosystem. It's extremely focused and his messaging is crystal clear.

FYI, that excerpt is from an internal document for his business that was made public. It's all about orienting his staff towards how they do things, and what they are here to do. To get everyone aligned on the mission. It's a pretty remarkable act of leadership; whether you like Mr. Beast or not.

author: spectrummasters
content:
I expect this will be common knowledge to the vets but might be new to others (as it is to me ) and thought it looked a fascinating technique im going to try and wanted to share :

I just watched Steve albini describe how he would use an equalizer in a feedback loop to generate a resonant frequency, then blend that tone with the original kick drum signal to allow him to choose a complementary pitch/note with the eq and via the feedback loop also add sustain to taste . 
If others know a better routing please do correct me : i think he sent the kick to the eq as an aux (not an insert), then brings the return back in a new channel , then sends that channel back to the eq again, creating the feedback loop and blends that into the mix to support the untreated kick. 
I feel this is a little different to regular ITB parallels or VOG processing in that he’s creating a feedback loop/resonance at a chosen note …sort of like synthesising an 808 ? Kinda genius. 
(This is happening OTB with hardware )

author: cian riordan
content: Baking isn’t necessarily something you can do over and over again… eventually, the oxide will just lift off the tape for good and it’ll be stuck to your heads and tape guides. There’s surely some decent one-pass reels available in LA or Nashville markets, but if I were you, start off in a good foot and just invest in some new reels to get you going. I assume you’re doing layback and not actually tracking/storing on tape? I have t used the new RTM but ATR has been reliable in my experience.

author: Adam Thein

author: Zack Hames
content: This is interesting - i remember seeing a steve albini video (and i think some other folks) talking about how analog tape is the most reliable archival format (specifically over digital) because the equipment and playback will "always" exist and be able to happen, etc. but I mean fuck what are you supposed to do, every so often archive your entire tape catalog to brand new tape? (not literally asking because everyone does digital archival, but just thinking out loud)

author: Zack Hames

author: cian riordan

author: cian riordan
content: But to be fair, tape is pretty robust. I’ve smashed it on the ground, uncrumpled from the trash, spools up fine

author: Zack Hames
content:
That is cool. I was nervous messing with it early on (literally have touched tape less than 10 times) and it really is robust. it's not overly fragile by any means. I think it's lovely.
makes me appreciate both sides, digital and analog. 
thanks again for all the info guys.

author: cian riordan
content: I just cold reached out to Eric V. after I met him through Matt. Told him I wanted to just hang on the couch for a day and watch him work. Two weeks later I'm moving to LA to work for him. @Tyler Graham hit me on this discord forum almost 4 years ago to come by for coffee -- he ended up working as my mix assistant until this past summer... he is now the head engineer at a new studio in town.

author: cian riordan
content: Figure out what you wanna learn and who you wanna learn it from first. Then start plotting the path to get there.

author: cian riordan
content: But also realize that mentorship does not equal a career... you still need to be able to operate on your own two feet, outside the shadow of whoever you're trying to work for.

Those overheads are unlikely the biggest part of the sound, and certainly more focused for cymbals than for the shells. The snare mic itself is going to be dead center and loud enough.

author: cian riordan
content: There’s no compromise if you space them correctly

author: cian riordan
content: If you space them correctly, snare is in the middle, you get full width

author: cian riordan
content: (Only if you want your snare in the center of the image)

author: cian riordan
content: Easiest way is grab a cable or some string, put it on the center of the snare (or on the right side of the rim, closest to the kick) and measure out each overhead to its capsule. Match that and it’s a great starting place.

author: Zack Hames
content: I like what @cian riordan is saying, about you can have the snare centered and have width if placed correctly. You have an advantage since you're recording yourself in your own space. you're not up against a clock of someone else's studio or someone else's time.

author: Zack Hames
content: a HUGE thing for me has been to not give a flying fuck what it sounds like in solo. It's a hard habit to break. 100% easier said than done.

author: Zack Hames
content: I am sure there's a perfect world where the snare is centered in the OH's and is "distant" sounding enough that it doesn't negatively affect the close mic, etc.

author: Zack Hames
content: my OH's are 100% to capture the cymbals, unless I am trying to make the OH's a full perfect capture of the drum kit - ala jazz or folk or something more naturalistic

author: Zack Hames

author: Zack Hames
content:
what you're saying makes sense. Couple things to try;

1. different click sound! I really like "marimba 2" in pro tools for some reason. really easy to hear always, feels REALLY on time.

2. Maybe try having a timed delay on one of your drum signals you can play off of. like a 1/16 note or triplet echo very faintly that, when you're in the pocket, grooves with your drumming. might be tough if you're doing really busy proggy stuff or if you're really worried about timing from an OCD perspective.

3. if you have scratch guitar/bass tracks that were tracked to a click/perfectly gridded drum thing, playing along to that is usually far more inspiring and you can rely less on the click because you can just listen to the instruments.

4. This is where having someone else record you helps. you might be totally in your head about this. a "producer" could be like "bro that take was legit perfect"

author: Zack Hames
content: even if you FELT weird about it.

author: cian riordan
content: Nothing beats the ease and flexibility of recording drums or a band through a console. It speeds up and simplifies the process so much... I absolutely hate recording without one. But will it wound better or worse than a stacked 500 series rack with decent pres and EQs? Probably not... will just sound different.

author: cian riordan
content: The advantages of the console are much more work flow and less sonics.

author: cian riordan
content: I love being able to gain up a mic pre on a console to where its saturating or clipping, and then trim the level back with the fader before it hits the computer

author: cian riordan
content: you can do the same thing on a 500 pre with a gain knob and and output attenuator

author: cian riordan
content: but its less tactile. With a console, everything for that channel is right there in front of you: mic gain, EQ, aux sends, level to pro tools, etc.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
also a clipper isn't just an envelope shaper, it's essentially a form of distortion
so if you replace "clipper" with "saturation" in your question, the transient designer doesn't sound all that out of place because as kidcutler pointed out it's doing more than just doing -1 and then +1

author: Will Melones
content: Wouldn’t it also even out the transients in a more consistent way than compression? Lop the jagged peaks off to zero, and then regenerate all the transients equally and controllably?

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: depends on the compressor (technically you can use lookahead/super fast attack and a very high ratio to do the same thing) but yea

author: Bryan DiMaio
content: oh yeah sorry I wasn't more clear in my response to will, that's essentially what I meant (doing the transient stuff without the harmonic stuff with a limiter)
